data.name: Luzern-Engelberg Express
data.abstract: Enjoy a relaxing, comfortable and rapid journey to Engelberg, an excellent day-trip destination. The newly-refurbished 1st class panorama coach of Luzern-Engelberg Express offers a particularly comfortable journey and spectacular views. The train will whisk you in just 47 minutes from the city, past Lake Lucerne and into the Engelberg valley, where you will pass through delightful villages nestling at the foot of increasingly steep and lofty mountains.
data.description:
What a way to the top of Central Switzerland 
The monastery village of Engelberg offers a wide range of activities and is worth a visit in both summer and winter. The Titlis-Rotair aerial cable car will lift you up to 3238 metres above sea level, to the eternal snow and ice of the Titlis range, and to many more views that will make your heart soar! 

www.zentralbahn.ch/en/luzern-engelberg-express [www.zentralbahn.ch/en/luzern-engelberg-express] 

Engelbart’s treasure – for real pirates only. 
Engelbart’s treasure is an exciting adventure trip from May to Octobre along the Zentralbahn line from Lucerne to Engelberg. The object is to find the band of pirates under the command of not-terribly-fearsome Captain Engelbart and join them in the search for the lost treasure. And there is no treasure hunt complete without a treasure chest! Have fun! 

www.zentralbahn.ch/en/engelbart [www.zentralbahn.ch/en/engelbart] TIMETABLE

From Lucerne: every hour from 6:010 a.m. to 8:10 p.m. 
From Engelberg: every hour from 6:01 a.m. to 9:01 p.m. 

Timetable valid until 13 December 2014

data.name: Kunstmuseum Luzern
data.abstract: The Kunstmuseum Luzern is located on the top floor of the Culture and Convention Center Lucerne (KKL), and was designed by Parisian architect Jean Nouvel as well.
data.description:
Covering an area of 2'100 square meters, the museum has changing exhibitions displaying significant works of modern art, as well as exhibitions from the museum's own collection, with an emphasis on 19th and 20th century landscape painting and international art from 1960. The architectural simplicity of the museum and the sophisticated use of light make every visit a genuine cultural experience.

For the current exhibition program, please visit the direct website of the Museum of Art Lucerne.

data.name: BLS RegioExpress Bern - Luzern
data.abstract: The BLS RegioExpress will bring you to one of Switzerland's most original areas.
data.description:
Route: 
Bern - Konolfingen - Langnau - Trubschachen - Schüpfheim - Wolhusen - Lucerne

The BLS RegioExpress trains run between Bern and Lucerne at hourly intervals. Travel time: approx. 1h30.

The route from Bern to Lucerne through the Emmental Valley and Entlebuch is a secret tip among Swiss train routes. Typical for the Emmental are the farmhouses with deep roofs that dot the rolling hills. Cows grazing on the lush green meadows supply the milk for the world-famous Emmental cheese with the large holes. Visitors who continue their journey through Entlebuch traverse Switzerland’s first UNESCO Biosphere Reserve. Fascinating moorlands and a multifaceted flora and fauna characterize this award-winning landscape. It is worthwhile to make stops en route: in Schüpfheim the PostBus “Panorama Route Express” awaits visitors and takes them through the Lammschlucht, a canyon, to Sörenberg and further on via the panoramic route to Giswil, where one can get train connections to Lucerne and Interlaken. The Kambly experience in Trubschachen, which lets visitors immerse themselves with all their senses into the secrets of pastry art, is worth a visit as well. Those who prefer exotic plants will be in their element in the Tropical House Wolhusen with its variety of tropical plants and crops.
No seat reservations possible.

data.name: Hofkirche St. Leodegar (Court Church of St. Leodegar) Luzern
data.abstract: St. Leodegar was founded in the mid-8th century, part of the monastery which in turn founded Lucerne. A Gothic church preceded the existing German Renaissance building, but was largely destroyed by fire in 1633. Only the towers, St. Mary's altar and a few religious objects remain in the existing 17th-century building.
data.description: St. Leodegar's white stone interior is generously furnished with gilt statuary and altars. Ornate wooden pews comprise the south half of the sanctuary, while simpler wooden seats occupy the north, a reminder of an earlier time when wealthy and poor parishioners worshiped apart. Near the center of the sanctuary on a supporting pillar a plaque honors Ludwig Pfyffer von Altishofen. The rich 17th-century Swiss mercenary was instrumental in bringing a Jesuit contingent to Lucerne, thus introducing the Counter Reformation to Switzerland.

data.name: A feast for the palate in the VILLA Schweizerhof
data.abstract: The Hotel Schweizerhof Luzern has been responsible for the VILLA Schweizerhof restaurant since 2017. The historic building is distinguished by its wonderful location with stunning views of the lake and mountains, while its park conveys a soothing tranquillity.
data.description: VILLA chef de cuisine Marcel Ineichen and his team delight guests with their regional cuisine. They set great store in using local and seasonal products – whether vegetables, meat or wine – and for this reason work closely with all regional suppliers. Ineichen, who has always been a proponent of cooking with herbs, has an extensive, beautiful and wonderfully fragrant herb garden, which serves as daily inspiration for his team in showcasing new and sumptuous creations.

data.name: Historical Points
data.abstract: The city that began as a monastery. Lucerne traces its roots directly to St.Leodegar monastery, a small 8th century Benedictine cloister. Over the centuries a community grew along the Reuss River from the monastery to a nearby settlement. Historians regard Lucerne’s birth date to be 1178, when the parish was officially transferred from the monastery to the city. Middle Age fortifications, such as the famous Chapel Bridge, are timeless witnesses of the city’s rapid growth.
data.description:
HIGHLIGHTS IN LUZERN.
Religious sites [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/interests/excursions/religious-sites.html?start=26]
Overnight at a monestary [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/accommodation/other_types/extraordinary-hotels-in-switzerland/overnights-in-a-monastery.html]
Christmas Markets [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/event_calendar/event_results.cfm?f2=stxmas] 
NICHOLAS VON FLÜE
St. Nicholas of Flüe lived in the 15th century at a quiet river gorge near Lucerne. Commonly called “Brother Klaus,” he began his life as a successful farmer, town councilor and husband. But at 50 Nicholas felt God’s pull toward a life of seclusion. With the support of his wife and 10 children, Brother Klaus became a hermit and lived out his remaining years as a spiritual counselor and skillful arbitrator of political disputes. He was instrumental in arbitrating several treaties and political disputes, earning a reputation as a peacemaker and the role of Switzerland’s patron saint, being respected by Catholics and Protestants alike. Several sites related to his life are active pilgrimage sites, including his home and retreat in Ranft George near Flüeli-Ranft and his grave in Sachseln. 

ABBEY OF EINSIEDELN
In 828 Meinrad, a Ben edictine monk from Lake Constance, withdrew as a hermit to a secluded mountain valley east of Lucerne. There, Meinrad lived and prayed in solitude until 861, when he was killed by bandits. St.Meinrad’s retreat forms the core of the monastery at Einsiedeln, located only 1 hour east of Lucerne. Set on the location of St.Meinrad’s retreat, Einsiedeln (which means “hermitage”) has attracted the devout for over 1,000 years. Eberhart became the first abbot of the community under Benedictine rule in the 10th century. Pilgrimage to the monastery began no later than the 14th century, when the monastery acquired the Black Madonna, an icon so named for the black candle smoke that colors her skin and the infant Jesus. The Black Madonna is usually clothed in elaborate attire and resides in the Lady Chapel, which rests over the site of St.Meinrad’s cell. The chapel in turn resides within the nave of the baroque Abbey Church. Huldrych Zwingli, leader of the Swiss Reformation, served briefly as a priest at Einsiedeln but moved to Zürich where he persuaded thousands to join the Protestant Reformation.

JESUIT CHURCH
The Jesuit Church is the first large sacral Baroque building in Switzerland and was constructed in 1666 by Father Christoph Vogler for the Jesuits. The vault was redecorated in the mid-18th century. The original vestments of Brother Klaus, are stored in the inner chapel.
THE INTERNATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE REFORMATION
This museum is a must-see for religious visitors that come to Geneva, Switzerland. It begins with an emphasis on the Bible and includes some of the oldest French and English Bibles. Unique objects, manuscripts, rare books, engravings and paintings illustrate the close ties of Geneva and John Calvin to the Reformation.
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/interests/excursions/religious-sites/musee-international-de-la-reforme-international-museum-of-the-reformation-genf.html]
OVERNIGHT IN A MONASTERY
Experience how it is to live in a monastery and overnight in one of the various abbeys and monasteries in Switzerland that offer simple accommodation. Some even offer their own mountain hut refuge to rent, like the convent of St.John in Muestair
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/accommodation/other_types/extraordinary-hotels-in-switzerland/overnights-in-a-monastery.html?all]
THE PILGRIMAGE WAY OF ST. JAMES ALONG SWITZERLAND’S BREATHTAKING MOUNTAIN SCENERY.
Walk or cycle on St. James' footsteps, following his ways through the breathtaking mountain scenery of Switzerland to Santiago de Compostela. Take your time to visit some of the traditional pilgrims' stations.
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/home/summervacations/excursion-summer/summer-mountain-tips/the-way-itself-is-the-goal.html]
CHRISTMAS MARKETS.
The Christmas season will soon be here again.. as well as the traditional Christmas markets in Switzerland. Montreux is home to the largest one, Bremgarten (Aargau) to one of the biggest ones in terms of vendors. The highest one can be visited on Mt. Pilatus. Others can be found in Huttwil (Bern), Zürich or Basel. 
more info [http://www.myswitzerland.com/en/service-updates/events.html?strubrik=2161]

data.name: Photo Spot Lucerne
data.abstract: The Lucerne hotel icon, modelled after Neuschwanstein Castle, was built by Emil Vogt in 1888 in one of Switzerland’s finest hotel locations. Martyn Lawrence Bullard, a world-renown interior designer, has revived the historic charm of Château Gütsch, putting great emphasis on small details – from the stuccoed ceiling to the hand-painted wood panelling. Just as in years past, the view from the rooftops of the old town over Lake Lucerne and the mountains is still spectacular.

data.name: Treno Gottardo
data.abstract: ​The Treno Gottardo runs hourly over the 120-year-old Gotthard panorama line to the sun-kissed corner of Switzerland. The panoramic ride promises impressive views of rugged mountain faces and deep blue lakes as well as plenty of Mediterranean flair with palm trees and stately residences.
data.description:
Bustling cities, historic buildings and a great variety of nature and leisure activities – all of this can be experienced on the Treno Gottardo. The diversity of Switzerland with one single train! The new train, equipped with bistro zone and family area, runs hourly from Zurich, Basel and Lucerne to Locarno. Travel most comfortably along lakes and mountains over the historic Gotthard panorama route right to Locarno in the sun-kissed corner of Switzerland. Benvenuti!


FACTS TRENO GOTTARDO
Route: Zürich/Basel/Luzern – Bellinzona – Locarno

Duration: Zürich – Locarno: 3 h 20 min
Basel – Locarno: 4 h 22 min
Luzern – Locarno: 3 h 7 min 

EXCURSION TIPS
 * Lucerne [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/lucerne/]with its numerous sights such as the chapel bridge or the lion's monument
 * Lake Lucerne [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/boat-cruises-on-lake-lucerne/] with its impressive fleet of steamboats
 * Altdorf [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/altdorf/], main town of the canton of Uri, with the world famous Tell monument
 * The 1882 inaugurated Gotthard panorama route with the church of Wassen that can be seen from three different angles during the ride
 * The Leventina [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/leventina/]with its spectacular surroundings – with the steep funicular railway to Lake Ritom and the Strada Alta, or by cableway to Lake Tremorgio
 * The castles of Bellinzona [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/the-fortress-of-bellinzona/], part of UNESCO World Heritage since the year 2000
 * Locarno [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/locarno/]with its bustling Piazza Grande, Lake Maggiore and the famous pilgrimage church Madonna del Sasso

FOOD & BEVERAGES
Two bistro zones with snack and beverage vending machines as well as a coffee maker.

TIMETABLE

TICKET

Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

RESERVATION

data.name: Trochenmatt
data.abstract: Mt. Pilatus - landmark mountain of Lucerne, the city of lights - is very popular with hikers and with excursionists in general. Its North Face is home to Krienseregg, a popular recreational area, and Alp Fräkmünt, a great vantage point.
data.description:
These mountains are also superbly suited for top-notch biking tours. Technical trails are here the order of the day. You will ascend plenty of meters in altitude. The vistas of the Lake Lucerne Valley basin are simply spectacular. On the other side the deeply cut Eigen Valley is spread out before your eyes. This picturesque spot presents itself in singular solitude - there is hardly a soul to be seen.
Begin and end of tour: Kriens
Technical requirements: challenging
Physical fitness: extreme
Distance: 38.6 km
Total altitude meters: 1721 m
Biking time: 3:30 - 5:30 (hours, minutes)
Elevation start and end of tour: 476 m
Culmination point: 1461 m
Season: Mai - November
Gastronomy: Kriens, Fräkmünt, Unter Lauelen, Stäfeli, Rosshütte
Overnight: Kriens
Access starting point: Busse ab Luzern
Access point of arrival: Busse nach Luzern
Literature: www.bike-explorer.ch [http://www.bike-explorer.ch]
Kriens - Fräkmünt - Lauelenegg - Unter Lauelen - Trochenmatt - Moos - Eigental - Chraigütsch - Kriens

The bike tour begins in Kriens and takes you at first via the Krienseregg to the Fräkmünt Mountain. An ultra steep and ultra technical single track then runs down into the Upper Eigen Valley. Riding in the direction of the valley you will ascend Trochenmatt. On your way to the Stäfeli Mountain, where an Alpine inn beckons you to stop for a repast, you will espy the Mittagsgüpfi Mountain. Subsequently, the route continues downward in the direction of the right side of the valley. Later on, you will return to the Eigen Valley on lonely trails and paths. From Fuchsbüel a challenging ascent leads to the Ross Hut. The last section of the tour runs along the hiking trail down to Kriens.

Pictures: www.bike-explorer.ch

data.name: Dragon Moor - Nature-Adventure Krienseregg
data.abstract: We invite all visitors to a stop-over on the Krienseregg Mountain when they ascend Mt. Pilatus on the world's steepest cogwheel train, or by means of the aerial cableway and the panorama-gondola.
data.description:
Enjoy Krienseregg's beauty, defined by woodlands and the nationally important flat and high moors. Attractive hiking loops, an exciting playground for children and grill facities provided by Pilatus-Bahnen, invite you to tarry awhile. Pilu, the friendly Pilatus dragon, accompanies big and small visitors through the protected area. At four Dragon Moor platforms you will gain unique insights into nature.

How to get there:
By car: in the direction of Lucerne, exit Luzern Süd/Kriens.
By train /bus: Up to Lucerne Train station, then Trolley-Bus (No. 1) in the direction of Kriens up to stop "Linde/Pilatus". 5 minutes walk to the valley station of the gondola train.

data.name: Steam Ahead on 15 Scheduled Lake Steamers
data.abstract: Enjoy a trip on any of the 15 steam boats sailing on 8 Swiss lakes.
data.description: Switzerland is not only a country of mountains but also of lakes. Lakes means that one should have boats on them, preferably steamers. This is the case on on 8 Swiss lakes which has 16 lake steamers. Each one is a historic boat, which was restored for many million Swiss francs. Lake Luzern has the most of these behemoths (5 boats) which fascinate children as much as adults. Lake Geneva has 4 of these proud examples of the 19th century. Other wonderful examples are the Lötschberg on Lake Brienz, and the Blümlisalp on Lake Thun. A smaller specimen, the Greif, sails on Lake Zurich. Steam Ahoy!

data.name: Round Trip on the Kambly Cookie Train
data.abstract: The scenic Kambly Cookie Train connects the cities of Bern and Lucerne. Along the way, stop at the show confectionary where Switzerland's favorite cookies are produced: the Kambly Experience in Trubschachen.
data.description:
During a single day, visitors get to experience magnificent views of snow-covered summits while traveling along deep blue, pristine lakes, lush green meadows and picturesque farms and discover famous Swiss boutique cities. All those highlights are linked together on a scenic train ride rich in variety. 

On the Luzern–Interlaken Express of the Zentralbahn, guests enjoy a ride over Brünig pass, travel along five lakes and pass by a multitude of waterfalls and characteristic, quaint Swiss villages. The BLS Regional Express connects Berne and Lucerne, traversing the typical, rolling landscape of Emmental and passing the UNESCO biosphere Entlebuch. At the heart of idyllic Emmental, the train stops right in front of the Kambly Experience, where secrets of the art of patisserie are revealed. On the way there is the possibility to explore the interesting cities of Bern, Lucerne and Interlaken.FACTS
Route: Bern – Trubschachen – Luzern – Brienz – Interlaken – Bern
Distance: approx. 200 km
Duration: 5 h
EXCURSION TIPS
 * Schynige Platte – with its historic cog railway at more than 2,000 m a.s.l. 
 * Bern – historic city
 * Lucerne – Chapel Bridge
 * Harder Kulm – the local mountain of Interlaken

FOOD & BEVERAGES
No catering facilities on the train. Meal options in the cities of Bern, Lucerne, Interlaken and the Kambly Experience.TIMETABLE

data.name: Europe's Highest Covered Wooden Bridge
data.abstract: For centuries, people needed to climb down one treacherous side to climb up the other. In 1893, a wooden bridge was built over this gorge. it is 48 meters long and 100 meters high.
data.description:
The Ranft Gorge, created by the River Melchaa on its way from Melchsee-Frutt to Lake Alpnach, is quite deep and unpassable. For centuries, people needed to climb down one treacherous side to climb up the other. In 1893, a bridge was built over this gorge. it is 100 meters long and 100 meters high. This makes this covered wooden bridge connecting Kerns to Flüeli-Ranft the highest wooden bridge in Europe. 
The area is also well-known for a famous Swiss saint, Niklaus von der Flüe who was born in Flüeli-Ranft. To this day, the famous peace-maker's former home attracts tourists and pilgrims.

How to get there:
Drive or take public transportation from Luzern to Kerns, via Sarnen. The bridge is on one of the minor roads of Flüeli-Ranft.

data.name: Voralpen-Express
data.abstract: The gentle side of Switzerland: It’s not all 4000-metre mountains and deep ravines. On the Voralpen-Express, visitors discover a different kind of Switzerland – undulating hills, picturesque villages and lovely orchards.
data.description:
Voralpen-Express is the most appealing way to travel between Eastern and Central Switzerland. Starting from Eastern Switzerland’s urban centre of St. Gallen, whose Abbey district is a UNESCO world heritage site, the train traverses the 99 metre high Sitter viaduct and the rolling landscape of “Toggenburg”. Passing by Rapperswil and the impressive upland moor near Rothenthurm, the journey ends after a little over two hours in historic Lucerne on the shores of Lake Lucerne.
FACTS
Route: St. Gallen – Wattwil – Rapperswil – Arth Goldau – Luzern
Distance: 125 km 
Duration: 2 h 18 min
EXCURSION TIPS
St. Gallen [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/destinations/st-gallen/] and surrounding area
 * Abbey district and Abbey library
 * Säntis – one of the most breathtaking panoramas of Switzerland at 2505 m a.s.l. 
 * Appenzell region – tradition is important between Bodensee and Säntis 

Rapperswil [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/destinations/rapperswil-jona/] and surrounding area
 * Rapperswil castle
 * Lake Zurich Navigation – 2 steamboats and 12 motor boats regularly navigate Lake Zurich

Lucerne [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/destinations/lucerne/]
 * Lion’s Monument – in memorial of Swiss citizens who died in 1792 during the French Revolution 
 * Lake Lucerne boat tours
 * Landscape and Animal Park Goldau – refuge for stags, wolves, lynxes and other wild animals 

FOOD & BEVERAGES
Each train has a bistro coach with catering services.TIMETABLE
All connections here [http://www.sbb.ch/en/home.html]TICKET

data.name: Glacier Impressions on the Susten
data.abstract: This is how easy a glacier tour can be: get off the Swiss Post Bus at Hotel Steingletscher on the Susten Pass, shoulder your backpack, grab a hiking guide with map and off you go, comfortably hiking on well-groomed trails, without risks.
data.description:
The glacier trail Steinalp, which conveys you in the nick of time from the busy pass road into the High Alps. There are 15 stations with informative panels along the way. Within 2 hours you will come to know a lot of facts on the inner and outer life of the 5-km long river of ice. Moraines, Alpine flowers at the edge of the glacier, typical rock formations and characteristic landscape are pointed out and explained in lay terms. The trail gets close and almost enters the mouth of the glacier that looks like a black cave above the milky-white Lake Steinsee, before it ascends to the vantage point. From here the view sweeps over the limestone rocks of the Wendenstoecke across high moorland and mountain lakes, Alpine meadows and pine forest up to the icy glacier. 
A detailed brochure on the glacier trail is available at Hotel Steingletscher for CHF 5.--.

How to get there:
Drive or take public transportation from Meiringen or Luzern/Erstfeld/Wassen to Steingletscher on the Susten Pass.

data.name: Göscheneralp: Gentle Tourism and Hard Granite
data.abstract: The huge granite rock face that welcomes visitors to this area is the Gotthard Massif.
data.description:
The tranquil town of Göschenen is the gateway to the Schöllenen Gorge. Trains and cars descend into the mountain. The mountainscape is a paradise for Alpine hikers and climbers. At Lake Göschenen they will find a mountain idyll: granite walls, Alpine bogs, tranquility and untouched nature. At the Damma Glacier mountain inn there is an opportunity to purchase authentic regional products . Hiking trails wind around the lake and into the mountains. There are five mountain huts operated by the Swiss Alpine Club, overlooking the Sustenhorn, Dammastock and glacier fields. As if tossed there by a careless giant, granite boulders litter the area, interspersed with Alpine flora, such as Alpine roses and wild blueberries. They make great climbing experiences for beginners or for nature photographers. And because the area is committed to ecotourism, it is car-free, but a bus-on-demand will bring guests into this pristine nature paradise.

How to get there:
Drive or take public transportation from Luzern via Gotthard Route to Göschenen/Göschener Alp.

data.name: A visit to Lucerne Culture and Congress Centre
data.description: On this guided tour, guests get the opportunity to find out more about this landmark of the city of Lucerne. You will feel the magic of KKL Luzern, learn about Jean Nouvel’s architectural vision and experience the play of water and light for yourself. The highlight of the behind-the-scenes tour is a visit to the concert hall, whose acoustics are considered one of the best in the world. From the panoramic terrace there is a spectacular view of the lake and the mountains.

price.description: CHF 360 per group for private visits

data.name: Globi-Express
data.abstract: The Swiss have known and loved him from their childhood: the blue children’s book character Globi. Even on the road he is part of the party – on the Globi-Express of the Zentralbahn route from Lucerne to Engelberg.
data.description:
The ride on the Globi-Express from Lucerne to Engelberg makes children's hearts beat faster. The specially designed carriage takes the little guests into a Globi-world, with coloured walls, Globi-books and much more.

Globi experiences all kinds of adventures with his friends on the journey. If you look out of the train window on the way, you can solve the exciting Globi-riddle and, with a bit of luck, win a great surprise.FACTS
Route: Luzern–Engelberg 
Distance: approx. 35 km
Duration: 43 min
EXCURSION TIPS
 * Titlis – including Europe’s highest suspension bridge 
 * Swiss Museum of Transport Lucerne
 * Golden round trip on Pilatus
 * Glacier garden Lucerne
 * Rigi – Queen of the Mountains

FOOD & BEVERAGES
No catering facilities on the train.TIMETABLE
All connections here [http://www.sbb.ch/en/home.html]TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]
RESERVATIONS
No seat reservation possible – free seating.

data.name: Zytturm
data.abstract: Zyt Tower is one of nine towers that are part of the town fortifications of Lucerne. Two giants carry the face of its time-honored clock on its façade. There are nine more historic tower clocks inside the tower.
data.description:
Since the late Middle Ages the Zyt Tower Clock has had the right to chime first: it chimes one minute before all other public clocks in Lucerne. And since late medieval times, a person tasked with this responsibility has wound the tower clock on a daily basis. The city watchmaker Jörg Spöring, who carried out his duty for 50 years, fulfilled the assignment till 2011. Within that time frame he collected nine more historic clocks from the region. They are now exhibited inside the tower – on six creaky platforms. The platform made of the oldest wood is crafted from wood dating back to the year 1403. 

The clocks have old-fashioned, quaint names, such as Lieli, Horwer and Moosmatt Clock. The clocks were made between the 16th and 20th centuries. They document the history of the art of clock-making: in the beginning expert metalworkers constructed timekeepers out of iron, then the age of watchmaking arrived, and at the end of the 19th century the heyday of industrial watchmaking began. INFORMATION

The exhibition can be viewed daily from spring to fall. Admission is free.

data.name: Take a boat trip on the Saphir panorama yacht
data.abstract: The chic ambience, aqua terrace and gorgeous views of the lake, city and mountains all make for a relaxing and enjoyable trip. A boat trip on the Saphir panorama yacht around Lake Lucerne offers a feast for your senses.
data.description:
Sit back in the comfortable seats and enjoy stunning views on this one-hour trip around Lake Lucerne. Just like a convertible car, the roof can be opened to give you the feeling of being on a yacht, and closed again if the weather takes a turn for the worse. The main deck offers a unique aqua terrace that opens up directly onto the lake, and the bar serves a wide variety of refreshing drinks.

A free audio guide is available with interesting insights into the history of Lucerne, the surrounding area and the sights.

Being out on the water, with the wind in your hair and sun or rain on your face is the perfect way to relax.

data.name: Christmas in Lucerne
data.abstract: During the Advent season, Lucerne shines in a very special glow. Twinkling lights illuminate the picturesque alleyways and Lake Lucerne glistens serenely in all its beauty. A light scent of winter chill, mixed with cinnamon and mulled wine, wafts through the city. It's Christmas time in the city of lights.
data.description:
The shores of Lake Lucerne reflect the festively decorated houses and the majestic mountains, and the snow-covered peaks lend the scenery a particularly fairytale-like atmosphere. Skiing, sledging, ice skating, cross-country skiing or a winter hike: countless winter adventures await you in the Lucerne-Lake Lucerne Region.

In magical Lucerne, a magic awakens during the Advent season that casts a spell over everyone. Twinkling lights and Christmas music lead visitors from Christmas market to Christmas market, where they are spoiled with regional and international delicacies. Local producers showcase their handicrafts - the perfect opportunity to buy those last-minute Christmas presents. 

During the city tour "Tannengrün und Lichterglanz", a guide reveals the secrets of Santa Claus and the Christ Child and explains how the Christmas tree finds its way into the warm living room, how the lights find their place and much more. Advent in Lucerne is a time of wonder and contemplation, when people come together to enjoy the warmth and magic of this special time of year.

More information: Christmas in Lucerne [https://www.luzern.com/en/highlights/christmas-in-lucerne/]

data.name: Bürgenstock round trip
data.abstract: The imposing Bürgenstock, with its steep rock faces stretches along the southern edge of Lake Lucerne opposite the municipalities of Vitznau and Weggis. Thanks to the direct connection to the recreational area directly at the entrance of Lucerne, it takes just 30 minutes to travel to the Bürgenstock Hotel.
data.description:
The new shuttle boat from Lucerne to Kehrsiten-Bürgenstock and the newly built Bürgenstock railway take you directly to the heart of the resort. Once at your destination, you can enjoy the views at one of the many restaurants or at the highest point in the city of Lucerne, which can be accessed via the Hammetschwand Lift.

Daily connections every hour from 6 a.m. to midnight. It takes 30 minutes to travel from Lucerne to the Bürgenstock Hotel.

More information [https://issuu.com/buergenstockresort/docs/2020_fahrplan_ganzes_jahr_shuttle_kurs1-4?fr=xIAEoAT3_NTU1]

data.name: Neustadt walking route
data.abstract: South of the River Reuss and west of Lucerne train station lies the Hirschmatt-Neustadt district. You’ll discover this urban district on a city walk.
data.description:
Hirschmatt is a bustling and colourful district thanks to its mixture of small shops and boutiques, galleries, restaurants, cinemas, bars, clubs, hotels and apartments. On the walk through the most urban district of the city of Lucerne, you’ll find out about its history and architecture while also discovering it as it is today. The walk starts at Lucerne Theatre. You’ll then stroll along Hirschmattstrasse, across Pilatusstrasse to the Vögeligärtli, a popular park and playground. The discovery tour continues along Sempacherstrasse and Habsburgerstrasse, finishing at Helvetiagärtli.

More information [https://www.luzern.com/en/detail/poitype/outdooractivetour/poi/neustadt-walking-route/]

data.name: Town Hall
data.description: Built between 1602 and 1606 by Anton Isenmann in Italian Renaissance style and covered with a Bern farmhouse roof for weather purposes. The open arcades facing the Reuss still serve Today as a weekly marketplace. The Kornschütte hall above an earlier trading goods store, is used today as a concert and exhibition locale.

data.name: Vögeligärtli Park
data.abstract: Where circus artists and people running stalls once entertained people, there is now what is without a doubt one of the most popular green spaces in the city of Lucerne: the Vögeligärtli. Its name – meaning the “bird garden” – comes from the aviary that was built in the park in 1901.
data.description:
This picnic spot in the middle of the city was formerly also known as Sempacherplatz, Sempachergarten, Englischer Garten, Zentralplatz or Zentralmatte.

When the “Gasfabrik” gasworks from what was then Sempacherplatz was moved to another location in 1899, this cleared the way for the area to be used for a new purpose. Relaxation and leisure came to the fore here.

The Vögeligärtli was also the place where performers and people running stalls gathered and entertained people. The Pilatus Circus and Arena Bühlmann with its travelling artists visited this place. Little by little, however, individual areas of the large green space were built on. The Lukaskirche (Church of St. Luke) was built in 1935, and the Central Library around 1950.

data.name: Spreuer Bridge
data.description: Was completed in 1408 as a part of the city fortification. Between 1626 and 1635 Kaspar Meglinger added 67 paintings that represent the “Dance of Death”. Called the Spreuer bridge because chaffs of wheat were thrown in the river here.

data.name: Beromünster Radio Trail
data.abstract: The municipality of Beromünster is also known as the home of Swiss radio, because Radio Beromünster has ruled the airwaves of German-speaking Switzerland since the 1930s.. You can find out more about the radio’s history by hiking along the Beromünster Radio Trail.
data.description:
The Beromünster Radio Trail is one of many Swiss cultural trails. This gentle hike starts at Beromünster bus station and ends on the Blosenberg looking down on the transmission tower. The trail takes you past seven listening stations, where you can immerse yourself in the eventful history of the radio. The stations play original audio files and tell you more about the people who brought the radio to life. If, at the end, you want to find out even more about the radio’s history, join the 90-minute guided tour of the KKLB centre of art and culture. 



The trail is open 365 days a year and is freely accessible to all visitors. There’s a snackbar on the route and a barbecue spot at the radio transmission tower. You can also take part in guided tours along the Radio Trail, during which Wetz, an artist at the helm of the KKLB, and his team regale you with even more interesting anecdotes about the radio’s history.



More information [http://www.beromuenster-radioweg.ch]

data.name: Ufschötti
data.abstract: The “Ufschötti” – the extensive expanse of greenery by the lake – is the place half of Lucerne heads for in the summer A 200-metre-long strip of sandy beach gives all its visitors real seaside vibes.
data.description:
Ufschötti is just a few minutes south of Lucerne’s main train station.

The bathing spot on Lake Lucerne offers bathing enthusiasts and sun worshippers expansive areas where they can lie back and relax with a few trees offering plenty of shade and a large sandy beach. On these green spaces, visitors can – while of course taking others in the area into consideration – enjoy a game of football or frisbee or cook up a storm over the barbecue.

During the summer season, the Ufschötti kiosk and Ufschötti beach bar offer hot and cold snacks and drinks. Ufschötti also has showers and toilets available for visitors to use.

data.name: Gourmet tour
data.abstract: This journey of gastronomic discovery is a feast for all the senses.
data.description:
You’ll discover the finest local flavours and delicious regional specialities in enchanting settings. Browse the stalls of Lucerne’s colourful market, pick the freshest fruit in lush orchards, explore the secrets of organic farming and brewing and cheese- and chocolate-making, and taste an abundance of authentic, traditional delicacies along the way. Join gourmet tours, guided walks or simply follow your nose: you’re promised a mouth-watering adventure. 

Here you find detailed information on the route: PDF Gourmet tour [/-/media/st/documents/gtos/grand%20tour%20gpx%20daten/103_15k_04_gtos_regionale_routen_luzern_e.pdf] 
Hereafter, we present 10 suggestions for excursions along the tour.
TIPP 1: WILLISAU RINGLIS
This irresistible biscuit made with honey and lemon has been copied extensively, but the original comes from picturesque Willisau. The prestigious confectionery Amrein in the heart of the historic town has been baking them to the same recipe since 1850. Connoisseurs use an elbow to break each Ringli into four pieces, and then place them on the tongue one by one to melt slowly and release all their flavours. TIPP 2: EXPERIENCE AGROVISION
This attractive project invites you to explore healthy nutrition with all your senses. The 40-hectare farm in the rural community of Alberswil produces, processes and sells a range of top-quality organic food. Join a guided tour or simply stroll around the site: discover the world of eco-friendly, sustainable farming through a venture that reinterprets traditional agriculture as a contemporary craft. TIPP 3: HOCHSTAMM SEETAL AG
A high-stem tree is one with a tall trunk and high crown, the kind familiar from traditional orchards. The landscape around the Seetal valley and Lake Sempach boasts an abundance of such trees, which create a picturesque sea of blossom in spring. As well as producing a mouth-watering variety of fruit, these trees provide a diverse habitat for wildlife including nearly 50 species of breeding birds. TIPP 4: LUCERNE MARKET
Lucerne’s market, held on Tuesday and Saturday mornings, is one of the most attractive in Switzerland. Stallholders sell everything from regional specialities and Mediterranean delicacies to flowers and crafts, all against the pretty backdrop of the Old Town. The stalls are laid out along the River Reuss: on the Rathausquai and Unter der Egg (right bank) and the Jesuitenplatz and Bahnhofstrasse (left bank). TIPP 5: AESCHBACH CHOCOLATIER, CHOCOWELT
For enthusiasts, the words Aeschbach Chocolatier conjure images of earthly bliss. At the company’s headquarters in Root, near Lucerne, visitors can see how the divine specialities are made by hand. The interactive ChocoWorld tells the mouth-watering story from cocoa bean to finished product – with tastings, of course. And at the ChocoCafé, ChocoBistro and ChocoShop, chocoholics are in seventh heaven. TIPP 6: GASTRONOMIC WALKS OBWALDEN
Two gastronomic trails in the Obwalden region bring you from one traditional restaurant to the next, either on foot or by bike. Along the Giswil Historical Trail, you’ll not only enjoy the regional specialities ordered in advance, you’ll also find ancient farmhouses, old wells and the only water-powered “hammer” sawmill in Switzerland. On the walk along Lake Sarnen, pristine nature takes pride of place. TIPP 7: CHEESE DAIRY, ABBY ENGELBERG
Switzerland’s only visitor cheese dairy located in a working monastery is famous for its “Engelberger Klosterglocke”, shaped like one of the monastery’s bells. Visitors can watch the cheese being made by hand. The attractive restaurant serves dishes made with the delicacy as well as other specialities – from cheese tarts and fondue to raclette prepared at the table and a range of delicious desserts. TIPP 8: SUVOROV HOUSE, ALTDORF
General Suvorov was the commander of the Russian army fighting French revolutionary forces in Switzerland in 1799, and during his retreat over the Alps to Russia he made his quarters in this building. It is the oldest town house in canton Uri, and the most important historically. The beautifully restored interiors are full of charm: an ideal setting in which to enjoy wine and delicacies from the region. TIPP 9: DISTILLERY "DETTLING KIRSCHWELT", BRUNNEN
The region around Brunnen is famous for its cherries and kirsch – cherry brandy. The ideal place to discover the secrets of this spirit bursting with flavour is the visitor centre of Dettling, six-time winner of the “World Class Distillery” label. A guided tour through “Dettling Kirschwelt” offers a sensory journey through the world of the legendary drink, with opportunities to taste selected varieties. TIPP 10: GINGERBRED MUSEUM, EINSIEDELN
The “Schafbock” is a kind of gingerbread originally intended as nourishment or a souvenir for pilgrims to the famous baroque monastery at Einsiedeln. Today the delicacy is famous throughout Switzerland, and even has its own museum: the Schafbock and Gingerbread Museum, located beside the nostalgic Goldalpfel bakery shop. The whole premises have been restored to the style of their late-19th-century heyday. INFORMATION

Careful planning is a prerequisite for an enjoyable tour. Please inform about the weather and road conditions beforehand at the local information point. According to the season and the weather conditions, the route might be closed or interrupted.

data.name: Lucerne Railroad Station
data.description: After the fire of 1971 the whole station area was newly built. Quite unique is the transparent entrance hall with the interesting roof, designed by the Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava. The main portal of the old train station is today a gate on Station Square.

data.name: Wintersports in Lucerne
data.abstract: Curling, Eisstock or Icehockey – a group game on ice is fun for everyone!
data.description: Curling the beloved tactical game of the winterolympics. Try it yourself, our experienced instructors will explain you the rules and guide you on the icerink. Eisstock (Ice poole) shooting - a kind of bowling on ice, needs no prior knowledge and is a fun sport for each team. A Icehockey match in full gear - from tightening the equipment until the victory celebration a hard game but also a lot of laughter.

data.name: Seebad
data.abstract: The Seebad lakeside baths offer perfect seasonal bathing pleasure in the heart of the city of Lucerne. It is open for swimmers until 8 p.m. in summer, after which it is dedicated to restaurant-goers for the rest of the evening. As well as bathing, swimming, and sunbathing, massage and yoga are also available.
data.description:
On Lucerne’s high-profile Nationalquai, right in front of the historic hotel buildings, bathers can take a refreshing dip in the pristine waters of the lake, exercise and relax on the sun deck or in the shade.

From the outside, the structure, which dates back to 1884/85, just looks like a huge wooden box, but once you cross the footbridge into the interior you will immediately succumb to the charm of a wonderful Belle Epoque bathing space. The wooden structure contains simple changing facilities around the two internal areas with lake water pools. If they swim towards the lake, bathers will soon find themselves in open water.

The Seebad is particularly busy at weekends, during lunch hour and in the evenings, when people are looking for some refreshment during their break or after work. There is an impressive unobstructed view of the Pilatus, the KKL Culture and Convention Centre and Lucerne train station on the lake side and from the roof terrace. A simple restaurant and bar service round off the available facilities.

Getting there: By train to Lucerne. Bus no. 6/8/24 from the train station, direction “Verkehrshaus/Lido/Würzenbach”, “Casino Palace” stop. By car (“Casino-Palace” and “National” parking garages).

data.name: Ice poole shooting fun
data.abstract: Lucerne’s ice center offers winter-based group activities right at the heart of the city. Ice poole shooting calls for team spirit.
data.description: Ice poole shooting the beloved tactical game. Try it yourself, our experienced instructors will explain you the rules and guide you. Ice poole shooting – a kind of bowling on ice, needs no prior knowledge and is a fun sport for each team. From the beginning until the victory celebration an amusing game with a lot of laughter.

data.name: Chocolate heaven
data.abstract: After a tasting, the whole family can learn how to make chocolate in the chocolatier’s workshop.
data.description: This family activity offers young and old alike the chance to visit Max Chocolatier’s atelier in Lucerne. There, during the tasting, they can first watch a chocolate expert and see how works of art are lovingly created by hand. In addition, you can try the current season’s range. On the next floor of Chocolate Heaven, participants can try their hand at being a chocolatier for themselves. They will pour bars and mould pralines under the watchful eye of the chocolatier.

data.name: Swiss Folklore Restaurant Stadtkeller
data.abstract: For a superb combination of good food, music and fun! With outstandingly good food and the unique Stadtkeller atmosphere, you can enjoy carefree hours in the midst of original Swiss folklore.
data.description:
Traditional Swiss customs featuring alphorns, cowbells, national costumes, flag throwing and yodelling makes your visit to the Stadtkeller an unforgettable experience. A unique historical place dating back to the 12th century. Restaurant is air-conditioned and open in summertime. During the winter months, the Stadtkeller becomes a musical venue. There is music almost every evening, with an emphasis on rock, pop, jazz and blues. There are often good local bands waiting to be “discovered”.
Original homemade Stadtkeller beer: Stadtkeller brews a very special beer, served in a stein, that tastes best when accompanied by traditional Swiss food.

data.name: Lucerne Lido
data.abstract: Lucerne’s lido sits on the shores of Lake Lucerne, spanning a length of over 300 metres.
data.description:
The sunbathing lawn is equally long, separated by a footpath behind the sandy beach. There are plenty more quiet spots to be found in the lido area. If the lake temperature is still a bit too cool for a swim, you can choose to use the heated swimming pool. The large children’s play area is also a great place to spend time. The play equipment has been chosen according to the latest educational and safety standards.

Getting there: By public transport from Lucerne train station with bus lines 6, 8 and 24 to “Verkehrshaus - Würzenbach” or by train S3 and UAE (“Verkehrshaus” stop). By car (public parking available).

data.name: The Lake in the Heart of Europe
data.abstract: Lake Lucerne is fascinating due to its picturesque landscape and historical sites.
data.description: Lake Lucerne (434 m above sea level) is fascinating due to its picturesque landscape and historical sites. 20 boats - 5 of which are nostalgic paddle-steamers - enable you to take round trips and offer endless possibilities for excursions which can also be combined with mountain railways along the lake.

data.name: Discover watchmaking "live"
data.abstract: Experience mechanical watchmaking live and discover the traditional craftsmanship of Chronoswiss.
data.description:
Are you fascinated by mechanical watches? Are you looking for an experience that is out of the ordinary, perhaps even a watch that not everyone owns or wears on their wrist?

Lucerne is home to a very special gem for watch lovers: Chronoswiss. This independent watch company, which is proudly family-owned and consciously sets itself apart from large corporations, is based in the heart of Lucerne. There, Chronoswiss offers the rare opportunity to discover watches and their manufacture at close quarters - an experience that cannot be found anywhere else.

From the design phase to the finest machining of the dials with century-old machines and the precise assembly - an enthusiastic team provides an insight into their craftsmanship. Chronoswiss' timepieces, often limited to a few pieces, can be tested and purchased directly in the atelier.

The opening hours for a visit to the atelier are Monday to Friday, from 09:00 to 17:30. Guided tours, which usually last a good hour, offer in-depth insights into the world of watchmaking and are available by appointment. Due to the direct insight into production times during working days and the high demand, Chronoswiss prioritises individuals and groups of up to 15 people with a keen interest in mechanical watches.

For further information and to register for a guided tour, please contact Beat Weinmann: beat.weinmann(at)chronoswiss.com directly.

data.name: Musegg Wall
data.abstract: The Water Tower, Chapel Bridge and Musegg Wall dominate the historical skyline of the city of Lucerne. However, the best view of the lake basin can be enjoyed from the path that runs along the Musegg Wall.
data.description:
The Musegg Wall and the nine Musegg Towers formed part of the town’s fortifications and today, visitors and locals can walk along many sections of the ramparts. The old natural stone walls provide a valuable and truly special habitat for endangered plants and animals, including jackdaws, common swifts and bats. There is also a Musegg Wall newspaper and guided tours are available.

Directly behind the wall lies the Hinter Musegg Farm – a chance to experience farm life in the heart of the city, with a farm shop, eatery and animals. The farm is organic and open stable doors offer visitors a glimpse into species-appropriate husbandry. Children and families can see alpacas, Highland cattle, mini pigs, hens and goats, while also getting a chance to work on the farm. This offer is available to school groups as well. Those wishing to find out more about the animals living here can follow the educational trail and solve a quiz to discover fascinating facts.

data.name: Voluntary work in the mountains
data.description:
In exchange for board and lodging, volunteers can play an active role in helping out a Swiss mountain farm family. While helping out, they will get to know the mountains from an entirely different perspective. The mountain work lasts at least five days, but volunteers can also work on a farm for longer than this. The activities on the farm are particularly diverse: from making hay to milking, making cheese and babysitting. Volunteers are being sought between the ages of 18 and 70. They will stay and eat on the farm for free as payment for their work. The assignments are organised and arranged by the not-for-profit organisation Caritas.

On bergeinsatz.ch you will find an overview of all the companies that are in need of voluntary support. Each company is portrayed individually with all available dates and places. You can book the desired date for the assignment (min. one week) directly online for this company.

Attention: Basic knowledge of the language of the region (German or French) is required in order to be able to communicate with the farm family. Due to legal regulations, only Swiss nationals or EU/EFTA citizens can volunteer in Switzerland.

data.name: Jesuitenkirche (Jesuit Church)
data.abstract: Lured to Lucerne by the wealthy Ludwig Pfyffer von Altishofen, the Jesuits brought the Counter Reformation to Lucerne in the 17th century; the elaborate Jesuitenkirche, dedicated to Francis Xavier, was constructed in 1666. Architects from Italy and Austria built what many believe to be the most beautiful Baroque church in Switzerland.
data.description: Rose and white plaster work embellishes an ethereal white interior. A massive pink altarpiece forms the focal point at the front of the sanctuary; although it resembles marble, it is actually stucco and plaster. The second side chapel on the right is dedicated to Brother Klaus. In place of an altarpiece stands a life-size statue of the beloved recluse clad in an authentic brown habit.

data.name: Peterskapelle (Peter's Chapel)
data.abstract: The Kapellplatz surrounds tiny Peterskapelle, an 18th-century church that was built over a 12th-century predecessor. This chapel also lends its name to the Kapellbrücke, the charming wooden bridge synonymous with Lucerne.
data.description:
The exterior walls of Peter's are adorned with several interesting works of art. An alabaster carving of the Mount of Olives remains from the previous church building. The fresco of Brother Klaus dates from the late 19th century, and the painting of St. Christopher is from the early 20th century.

More information [https://www.kathluzern.ch/peterskapelle/]

data.name: Girl power in the world of technology
data.abstract: On a themed tour, visitors will get to know aspects of Swiss transport history, in which women play a key role.
data.description: This guided tour of the Swiss Museum of Transport in Lucerne presents projects and developments with the focus on women’s power in the world of technology. There are many examples in Swiss transport history where women have played and continue to play a major role. During the tour, visitors will also learn how the role of women has changed over the centuries. Then, as now, the secret of a successful team has been productive collaboration between both sexes. The guided tour on the topic of girl power in technology lasts a maximum of 2 hours.

data.name: ViaSbrinz - Where muleteers once travelled
data.abstract: The route: Stansstad/Alpnachstad – Jochpass/Brünigpass – Grimselpass – Obergesteln – Griespass – Ponte (I) The Sbrinz Route was named after the celebrated hard cheese from central Switzerland, which originated in the Engelberg valley and which was transported and traded along this route in great quantities in former times.
data.description:
The Sbrinz Route was named after the celebrated hard cheese from central Switzerland, which originated in the Engelberg valley and which was transported and traded along this route in great quantities in former times. The ViaSbrinz follows the transport route used for hard In the late middle ages, the mature hard cheese, known today as “Sbrinz“, was an export hit in central Switzerland and on the north Italian markets. Not least thanks to this cheese, the mule trail across the Grimsel and Gries passes to Domodossola developed into a well-established trading route. Old routes full of character and an unbeatable mountain landscape transform the ViaSbrinz today to an unforgettable hiking experience.

HIGHLIGHTS
Exhibition devoted to the history of muleteers and trade including a 3.5 km experience trail around the Sust, the manor house in Grafenort. Time stones - testimonies of their time. Muleteer Museum Meiringen. Walser Museum Ponte.

data.name: Eichhof Brewery Tour
data.abstract: Eichhof is a proud beer of a proud region. Brewed in the heart of Switzerland. A beer that has been appreciated throughout the whole country for more than 180 years.
data.description:
Nowadays we brew thirteen different varieties. One beer for every individual and every occasion. From the classic “Lager” to the strong “Barbara”. We use only the best ingredients: first-class malting barley, fine flavoured hops, yeast from our own breeding and pure water. During our varied brewery tour, we will show you how this unique beer experience is made.

CHF 20.00 per person incl. Tasting and little snack, smaller groups (less than 10 persons): CHF 200.00 per group

data.name: Swiss Chocolate Adventure
data.abstract: "Swiss Chocolate Adventure". Visitors will experience the chocolate adventure on an exciting journey.
data.description: A multimedia journey through the Swiss Chocolate Adventure shows how cocoa beans from Ghana are made into the famous Swiss chocolate. Visitors embark on a multimedia voyage of discovery to find out interesting facts about the discovery, origin, manufacture and transport of chocolate. See, hear, smell and taste: a number of themed islands that visitors travel around in special praliné-shaped cars appeal to all the senses.

data.name: Schwarzes Schaf
data.abstract: This stylish venue in the heart of Lucerne, the "city of lights", is transformed at night into a musical time machine, where people get together to have a good time and forget their everyday worries.

data.name: Bake your pizza at the Richemont bakery school
data.abstract: The Bakery school offers you the opportunity to create all sorts of pizza treats with our specialists.
data.description: While baking away, find out lots of interesting facts about the history of pizza and of course the bakery school itself. Then you are about to experience our baker’s Apero in the Backstube (bakehouse). The event can also be booked as a full evening meal, complete with salad, your own pizza and a dessert.

data.name: Max Chocolatier
data.abstract: “Who thought there would be a healthy chocolate heaven?”
data.description:
Once upon a time, there was a young boy whose mouth often bore telltale chocolate smudges. On 27 September 2009, the boy’s father made a dream come true. That day saw the opening of Max Chocolatier in Lucerne. Mixing a passion for chocolate with a pantry full of natural ingredients, a team of chocolate-making magicians and a file of secret recipes, Max Chocolatier set about turning sweet treats into heart-melting experiences. 

Celebrating a birthday, a great team, or simply your love of chocolate? Why not do it in chocolate paradise? We’d be happy to open the gates of our chocolate heavens in Lucerne or Zurich to welcome our guests. You’ll discover the secrets of Max Chocolatier during a 45-minute tasting. In Lucerne you can then put your knowledge into practice with your own 45-minute creative session, making chocolate with our experts. And a glance through the atelier window at the mountains and lake will leave you in no doubt about the Swissness of your craftsmanship!

data.name: Richard Wagner Museum Park
data.abstract: Richard Wagner lived here on the shores of Lake Lucerne for six years. The museum named after him is surrounded by an extensive park right by the lake, offering unique views of the mountains. The park can be reached within a 30-minute walk from Lucerne, along a wonderful lakeside path.
data.description:
Richard Wagner lived on this grand estate, now the Richard Wagner Museum in Tribschen on Lake Lucerne, with his second wife Cosima and his children from 1866 to 1872. On the ground floor of this former residence, visitors can view a collection on Richard Wagner and his time in Tribschen.

The city of Lucerne first acquired the country house and its expansive park spread over 30,000 square metres in 1931 in order to open it to the public. On the lake shore by the museum can now be found one of Lucerne’s most scenic children’s playgrounds. A number of benches invite visitors to linger and relax for a while.

data.name: Immersed in the world of chocolate
data.description: From cacao tree to exquisite chocolates: at the ChocoWorld experience, the production steps are interactively staged on 800 square metres for visitors to see, smell and sample. A big window also provides a fascinating insight into the ChocoManufactory. With the additional offer, visitors can even create a personalised chocolate bar from different ingredients.

price.description: CHF 15.00 per adult CHF 8.00 per child

data.name: Aeschbach Chocolatier: ChocoStudio
data.abstract: Immerse yourself in the world of chocolate and experience indulgence with all your senses. Whether cosy hours in the ChocoCafé, exciting insights in the ChocoWelt or exquisite delicacies in the ChocoBoutique - the ChocoDromo combines tradition, craftsmanship and a love of chocolate in one unique place.
data.description:
At the ChocoDromo in Root near Lucerne, everything revolves around the fascination of chocolate. The cosy ChocoCafé invites you to linger and indulge in fine coffee, tempting desserts and freshly prepared lunch menus. In the interactive ChocoWorld, young and old can immerse themselves in the magic of chocolate - from the origin of cocoa to the production of the finest chocolate specialities. The ChocoBoutique offers an exquisite selection of handmade specialities - perfect for enjoying or giving as a gift.

Even if you are looking for a special event for your employees, customers or your organisation: The ChocoDromo with the best view of Mount Pilatus offers a unique atmosphere for customised events. Combine your visit to ChocoWelt with a tour of the factory or a delicious aperitif, lunch or dinner, for example.

The interactive tour lasts around 60-90 minutes and can be experienced in German and English. We are happy to take bookings for groups of 10 or more or school classes.

data.abstract: Your team event: social commitment on a farm in the mountains.
data.description:
Caritas offers Corporate Volunteering in the Swiss Mountains. The one-day excursions help Swiss Mountain farmers to secure their existence and offer your employees an unforgettable team building experience.

data.name: City tour
data.abstract: During the city tour, visitors visit such world famous attractions as the Chapel Bridge with the octagonal Water Tower, the Jesuit Church and KKL Lucerne.
data.description: Learn about significant and playful aspects of Lucerne’s history and about the daily lives of its inhabitants. Discover hidden alleys, lively squares and also catch a glimpse of the city’s crowning glory, the Museggmauer wall.

data.name: Old Town boulevard in Lucerne
data.description: Lucerne's old town boulevard lies between city hall and Chapel Bridge along the river Reuss. Numerous restaurants invite our guests to sit at nicely arranged tables. Guests from all over the world stroll along the river and enjoy the "see and be seen"!

data.name: Mittlere Brücke / Pier
data.abstract: It may be “just” a bridge – but what a bridge! The Mittlere Brücke has come to symbolise the city of Basel. Opened back in 1226, it is one of the oldest Rhine crossings between Lake Constance and the North Sea.
data.description:
The bridge was initially used for local traffic, but in the 14th century, as the route over the Gotthard Pass took on international significance, it became an important Rhine crossing for long-distance trade. With the advent of electric trams – the “Drämmli” - the bridge had to make way for the new Mittlere Brücke, built in 1905 using granite from the north side of the Gotthard Massif. A copy of the old bridge chapel, the so-called “Käppelijoch”, where convicted criminals were sentenced to death in the Middle Ages, was erected in memory of the original structure – and is a wonderful place to enjoy the view of the Rhine.

The Mittlere Brücke links the fashionable Old Town on the left bank – known for the cathedral and Barfüsserplatz – with Kleinbasel, a district traditionally inhabited by workers and immigrants. Right next to the Mittlere Brücke, the Rhine boats moor at the pier. From here you can take a cruise to the Jean Tinguely Museum or even as far as Weil am Rhein, site of the Vitra Design Museum.

data.name: Loreto Chapel
data.abstract: This Baroque-style building, which was constructed in 1648 and occupies a particularly beautiful spot above Fribourg, is a small-scale copy of the Santa Casa de Loreto in Italy and offers wonderful views of the old town.
data.description:
The elegant little chapel owes its existence to the authorities of the city of Fribourg, who decided to build it in an effort to restore peace to Switzerland after the turmoil of the 16th century. Constructed by Jean-François de Reyff, a multi-talented Fribourg artist, the chapel is one of the most beautiful Baroque-era buildings in Switzerland. The terrace around the chapel offers magnificent views of Fribourg’s districts and bridges. The benches are the perfect spot to relax and enjoy the view at your leisure. The geometric paving, especially the cobblestones placed on their edges, also inspires meditation

The footpath to the Loreto Chapel is steep and may therefore be difficult for some visitors. The good news is that in summer there is a mini-train [https://www.fribourgtourisme.ch/de/P5303/minizug-von-freiburg] to take tourists to the top.

data.name: Talabfahrt Weglosen
data.abstract: Weglosen downhill descent. A classic favorite for ski cracks in search of a challenge.
data.description:
The Weglosen downhill descent is a popular and varying piste for experienced skiers - leading along an imposing rock face, small forest stretches, and over a bridge at the finish. And on enjoying the ride you also catch a glimpse of the Roggenstock and mountain station of the Weglosen-Seebli cable car. The Restaurant Sternen is also located where this piste begins, and whether inside or having taken a terrace seat you have lovely views of the Alps and surrounding ski region. On arriving at the finish Wendel’s chapel invites you to drop by too.
Starting point: Top station Sternen (1811 m a.s.l.)

Accessibility of starting point: aerial cableway, chairlift

Destination: Valley station Weglosen (1035 m a.s.l.)

Length: 6 km

Altitude difference: 776 Meter

Level of difficulty: advanced (normal slope)

Food and beverages: at the start, at the finish (Restaurant Sternen, Snackbar Wendel’s Kapelle)

data.name: Celebrate in the cultural monument
data.abstract: The Bourbaki Panorama can be found on the edge of Lucerne’s old town, right by the Lion Monument. Now a listed building, the museum was built in 1889 to display the famous Bourbaki Panorama. The picture gallery of the Bourbaki Panorama Museum can be exclusively booked or hired for a wide variety of guided tours, festive and information events and celebrations. An event at the museum surrounded by the huge panorama is a unique experience.
data.description:
The Bourbaki Panorama in Lucerne is a European cultural monument and forms the centrepiece of the building of the same name. Artist Edouard Castres tells a gripping story in monumental panoramic style (the image measures 112 x 10 metres, originally 112 x 14 metres), captured in this impressive painting in 1881.

Current socio-political issues can also be experienced at this lively location. Themed tours show how dynamically the past and present collide. Exclusive restoration tours offering a peek behind the scenes are also available and allow you to experience the panorama from a unique perspective.

additionalDescriptions.description: Boasting a central location in the heart of Lucerne, the Bourbaki Panorama is a very special venue. The museum rooms and other spaces around the listed building offer unique opportunities for staging events.

data.name: Dine on the move
data.abstract: Travelling in style. The trip from Zermatt to St. Moritz/Davos on the Glacier Express is a treat for all the senses as is a gourmet ride on the Golden- Pass Line from the Bernese Oberland to Lucerne. These panoramic routes are among the finest railway experiences to be had anywhere in the world – thanks to the breathtaking views, and to the gastronomic delights served in the dining car. Pure pleasure, in a stunning setting.
data.description:
GOLDENPASS CLASSIC
The dining car is shaped like a wine barrel. Glass in hand, you’ll glide past the most beautiful parts of Switzerland, from Zweisimmen to Montreux, pampered by the chefs and indulged by the scenery. More Information... [http://www.mob.ch] 

THE SALON BLEU ON WHEELS
The Belle Époque comes to life in this dining car in the legendary style of the Orient Express. Enjoy anything from a glass of champagne to a multi-course menu. Also available for private events. More Information... [http://www.railaway.ch/Deutsch/Extrazug/extrazug_salonBleu.html ] 

FONDUE UP ON THE MOUNTAIN, OR DOWN ON THE LAKE
Fondue is always great fun – even more so when the setting is special. You can enjoy one on Mount Rigi [http://www.rigi.ch], the panoramic mountain high above Lake Lucerne, as you travel on the vintage electric cog wheel railway dating from 1911; or on one of the much-loved fondue cruises [http://www.railaway.ch/Deutsch/Publikumsfahrten/bodenseefahrten.html] on Lake Constance. 

A TASTY TRIP THROUGH GRAUBÜNDEN
Fresh, seasonal cuisine, great wines and fine brandies are all served in the Gourmino, the nostalgic 1930s dining car that travels the network of the Rhaetian Railways. A year-round calendar offers travellers treats ranging from just-picked asparagus to Buurametzgeta (farmhouse meal featuring a variety of cured meats) and seasonal game dishes. More Information... [http://www.rhb.ch]
BREAKFAST WITH BOND – AND OTHER PEAK PLEASURES
Scaling the mighty peaks of the Alps gives you quite an appetite – even when you make the ascent in a cable car or funicular. Thankfully, when you get to the top, there are special treats in store, like the James Bond Breakfast (daily until 11am) at the Piz Gloria revolving restaurant on the Schilthorn [http://www.schilthorn.ch], where “On Her Majesty’s Secret Service” was filmed; or creamy Älplermakkaroni (alpine macaroni and cheese) on the Stanserhorn [http://www.stanserhorn.ch]; or a stylish dinner on the Brienzer Rothorn [http://www.brienz-rothorn-bahn.ch] after a spectacular ride on Switzerland’s oldest steam-powered cog railway.

data.name: Chamois in the Zwüschetmythen region
data.abstract: If you take an evening walk from Schwyz to the pass between the two Mythen mountains (1 h from Schwyz), you're very likely to see several chamois roving freely at close quarters.
data.description:
From the Zwischenmythen viewing point (1437m), marked with a large metal cross, your gaze wanders over the valley cirque from Schwyz to Brunnen with Lake Lucerne, and across Lake Lauerz to Mount Rigi. 

On the Alptal side is the cosy Zwüschet-Mythen Alpine inn. As well as beverages, you can savour local products from the inn's own meadow here. This meadow, nestled idyllically between the Grosser Mythen and the forest, is on the famous Schwyz Panorama Trail from the Sattel-Hochstuckli region to Hoch-Ybrig. Mountain railways take you from Rickenbach near Schwyz to the Rotenflue and from Alptal (Brunni) to the Holzegg. Accommodation is available in the romantic Holzegg ski hut or in the Holzegg mountain inn.

data.name: Lake Lucerne in a ship’s hold
data.description: The steam or motor boat travels across Lake Lucerne to Flüelen and back, 1st class (including a companion). The captain shows his wheelhouse, the engineers offer tours through the ship’s hold. Also, a delicious meal is served in the ship’s restaurant – with views of Rigi, Pilatus and Stanserhorn.

data.name: Photo Spot Lake Lucerne
data.abstract: In the distance you can see the Rütli meadow, the historic place where the forming of Switzerland is said to have occurred in 1291. With its 2,928 m (9,606 ft), the pyramidal peak of Urirotstock can be made out even farther in the back. The village of Seelisberg lies on a sunny terrace at 850 m.a.s.l. (2.788 ft), beneath the two mountains Niederbauen and Oberbauen. Lake Lucerne, in German literally ‘Four Forested Settlements Lake’, got its name because it is embedded in the four forest cantons of Uri, Schwyz, Obwalden and Nidwalden, and Lucerne.

data.name: Photo Spot Lake Lucerne Car Ferry
data.abstract: The only 'mobile photo spot' on the Grand Tour of Switzerland. In 1928, Alois Waser-Bucher, an entrepreneur from Nidwald, took interest in the Beckenried–Gersau car ferry project and, subsequently, had a ferry constructed in Uerikon on Lake Zurich in 1929. On Whit Sunday 1930, the ferry service was opened with the motor vessel ‘Tellsprung’ (‘Tell’s Leap’) carrying 20 cars. In 1959, a local hotelier bought the ferry and had it extensively rebuilt by Bodan Wharf on Lake Constance. The new ferry, which can carry up to 45 cars, started its service on Whit Saturday 1964, and has been owned by the F&R Group Beckenried since 2016.

data.name: Canoeing on Lake Lucerne
data.description: The guests spend either a half or a whole day on a tour by lake kayak or by canoe. A competent canoe guide shows them some breathtaking places and tells mystical stories of the lake. On the one-day tour, there is time for a picnic and a swim in the lake.

data.name: Beginner golf lessons overlooking Lake Lucerne
data.abstract: The nine-hole golf course at the Bürgenstock Resort in the foothills of the Alps boasts enchantingly unique mountain views and makes the perfect place for beginners to try their hand at golf.
data.description: In addition to three hotels, various restaurants, a 10,000 m2 spa and many other amenities, the new Bürgenstock Resort offers beginner golf lessons on its own golf course. Why not learn to play the game of games at an altitude of 500 metres? Participants learn to tee off, putt and follow golf course etiquette. And all this with a breathtaking view from 500 metres above Lake Lucerne.Info and registration [golf@burgenstockresort.com]

data.name: Paddling Fun on the Canoe Route on Lake Lucerne
data.abstract: Enjoy dipping your paddle in blue Lake Lucerne and feel the fresh lake air in your face. The Canoe Trail Lake Lucerne delights experienced canoeists and novices alike. This offer guarantees adventure and relaxation.
data.description:
You can choose among three routes - Buochs-Gersau, Gersau-Brunnen and Brunnen-Buochs, which run between the canoe stations of Brunnen, Buochs and Rotschuo (Gersau). All three routes guarantee adventure-rich canoe vacations and interesting day tours. If you prefer, you can combine these to create an attractive multi-day canoe tour and enjoy your time on the lake to the fullest. 

Kayaks and Canadian canoes can be rented at the campsite in Bouchs. Accommodation is available at the youth hostel in Gersau, and at the campsites in Brunnen and Buochs. Upon request, Canoe World Buochs organizes the return transport of visitors and canoes from Gersau or Brunnen. 
A canoe guide with integrated canoe map can be rented.

data.name: Klewenalp/Stockhütte - Niederbauen
data.abstract: 1,200 meters above the southern shore of Lake Lucerne. Three cableways run from Beckenried and Emmetten to the peaks. Scenic circular trails, hiking tours and walking paths.
data.description:
Family safaris are very popular. Klewenalp/Stockhütte–Seelisberg with several mountain train rides, PostBus and boat back to Beckenried.

The wildlife trail Emmetten reveals interesting information on the flora and fauna at the Oberbauenstock. In the Niederbauen area, the view from the Hunds-Chopf to Lake Uri, the ascent to Niederbauen Chulm, and alpine cheese in the Tritt Hut - are always rewarding experiences.
Height: 1,593 meters / 1,570 meters 

Accessibility: Train Lucerne–Stans, PostBus to Beckenried or Emmetten, or by ship from Lucerne to Beckenried; aerial cable car Beckenried–Klewenalp, Emmetten–Stockhütte and Emmetten-Niederbauen 

View: Panoramic view over the arms of Lake Lucerne, opposite the Rigi; the highlight of the vistas is the Niederbauen Chulm (1 hour 20 min from the mountain station) 

Attractions: Wide range of events and entertainment in the Klewenalp region; Wildlife Observation Trail Emmetten; Hanggliding from the Niederbauen (mountain station) Culinary delights: Restaurants on Klewenalp, Stockhütte, Niederbauen Mountain Station; catered Hut Alp Tritt (Niederbauen) 

Accommodation: Klewenalp: “Panorama” Mountain Inn (Berggasthaus) with double and multiple-bed rooms (100 persons), Naturfreundehaus (“Friends of Nature House”) with 2-bed and multiple-bed rooms (50 persons) Mountain Inn Klewenstock rooms and mattress camp (45 persons), Mountain Inn Tannibüel (50 persons) 

Stockhütte: Mountain Inn and Alpgädili (mountain hut) with 2-bed and multiple-bed rooms for 80 persons 

Niederbauen: Mountain Inn with Mountain Suite, 2-bed and multiple-bed rooms (62 persons) Groups: accommodation in many mountain inns upon request.

Winter: Winter sports region Klewenalp-Stockhütte up to 1,938 meters and snowshoe trails on the Niederbauen, winter hiking trails.

Special events: Country Festival in July; Yodelling Fair in the Mountain Chapel Klewenalp every second Sunday in the summer

Please note: fully included in the Swiss Travel Pass/GA travelcard. 
Book your Swiss Travel System ticket [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

data.name: Seilpark Rigi
data.abstract: The leisure park and sports facility is located in a scenic spot at the foot of Mt. Rigi, overlooking Lake Lucerne.
data.description: Sports and outdoor enthusiasts, families, clubs and companies will find this a fascinating experience. The facility offers parcours of various degrees of difficulty on over 70 safe platforms. Starting point is the Alpenhof, a well-known excursion destination with a restaurant and a playground for guests' children.

data.name: Exclusive sailing activities
data.abstract: Experience a few various hours on Lake Lucerne under sail. Our individually organized events will leave a lasting impression on all involved.
data.description: The popular sailing events are organized all over Lake Lucerne for groups of 1-60 participants. Whether further courses to leadership seminars, relaxing trips to further education, romantic trips for wedding parties, sporty sailing as a birthday present and much more. We offer a suitable program for every occasion. Whether windy in the Lake of Uri, imposing in front of the Lucerne skyline or relish in the Horwer basin in one of the surrounding restaurants: We have countless possibilities to work out a suitable offer for all requirements.

data.name: Winter canoeing tours on Lake Uri
data.abstract: Gliding over the still waters of Lake Uri – the southern end of Lake Lucerne – in a canoe is a truly magical experience in winter. This tour, which is for groups of at least three people, sets out from Brunnen to explore the fjord-like landscape.
data.description:
The ice crystals glisten and bare branches rise out of the water while the snow-covered Mythen are forever in the background as paddlers glide along on their two-hour tour. Protected against the cold and wrapped up warmly in special, insulated suits and warm clothing, you will take to the waters with an experienced guide. An adventure of a special kind.

More information [https://www.erlebnisregion-mythen.ch/de/buchen/erlebnisangebote/winterangebote/kanu-wintertouren/]

image.name: Winterkanutour auf dem Urnersee - 4
