data.name: ViaGottardo - It all began with the devil
data.abstract: Route: Basle/Schaffhausen - Lake Lucerne - Gotthard pass Lugano - Chiasso
data.description: Myth and history are omnipresent along the ViaGottardo. Two branches from Basle and Schaffhausen converge on the Lake of Lucerne and continue across the Gotthard pass to Chiasso. Again and again the traditional Swiss transit route provides new surprises. Apart from well-known attractions, natural and cultural treasures in hiding along the route are just waiting to be discovered.

data.name: Fun in the snow with views of a lake
data.abstract: Picturesque Lake Lucerne combined with a ski day at Klewenalp.
data.description: Anybody who is not familiar with the situation is a bit puzzled when skiers arrive in Beckenried in full gear – by boat, no less! The journey from Lucerne across Lake Lucerne is without doubt the most extraordinary arrival at a Swiss ski resort. Ten minutes later by cable car and then after a short ascent with snow shoes or touring skis, the freeriding fun begins, away from all the hustle and bustle.

data.name: To the Klewenalp with the Tell-Pass
data.abstract: Long tobogganing runs, glorious peaks and record-breaking cable cars: discover the Lucerne-Lake Lucerne Region with the Tell-Pass.
data.description:
From Lucerne to Beckenried by boat. And then up to the Klewenalp by cable car. Here, toboggans can be hired for just CHF 10 per day. From the Klewenalp, a 9km tobogganing run goes down through the winter wonderland via the Stockhütte to Emmetten. The postal bus and Zentralbahn railway will then return visitors to Lucerne. Travel freely on trains, buses, boats and various cable cars in Central Switzerland with the Tell-Pass. Prices begin at CHF 110 and the pass is available from two to ten days.
Tellpass [http://www.tellpass.ch/de/winter/ ]

data.name: Photo Spot Grosser Mythen
data.abstract: Exactly 47 hairpin bends lead to the Grosser Mythen, here also referred to as ‘Matterhorn of Central Switzerland’. Every year, around 30,000 hikers enjoy the breathtaking panorama at 1,898 m.a.s.l. (6,227 ft). The view into the valley shows ‘Old Schwyz’, the cradle of the Swiss Confederacy, with Lake Lucerne in the south as well as lakes Lauerz and Zug with Rigi and Rossberg to the west. It comes at no surprise that the Schwyz landmark has been immortalised as a mural in the National Council Chamber of the Federal Palace.
data.description:
Address:
Rickenbachstrasse 163
6432 Rickenbach

Parking: 
Cable car parking, metered

Footpath:

Change required at Fiescheralp station, 
footpath from mountain station 1 min.

data.name: Fronalpstock viewing platform
data.abstract: The striking viewing platform above Brunnen can be easily reached by chair lift from car-free Stoos. Gaze across the arms of Lake Lucerne to the Black Forest.
data.description:
The summit of the Fronalpstock boasts an unbeatable 360° panoramic view. Among the sights are the Glarus mountains Glärnisch and Tödi, Uri Rotstock, the central Swiss mountains Pilatus and the two Mythen, Solothurn’s local mountain, the Weissenstein and, across the border, the Vosges. The wide vista of ten lakes and the view down into Rütli, the Uri Reuss Valley and Lucerne are impressive.

The cosy and rustic summit restaurant as well as easy walks on the viewing plateau are ideal for connoisseurs. Children can stroke the mountain goats. The spacious playground is the ideal spot for fun and games with a spectacular view. Starting out from the Klingenstock chair lift, sure-footed hikers can reach the Fronalpstock via the well-developed, spectacular ridge path, which is partly secured by chains. The descent crosses alpine meadows - past Laui Alpine Farm - back to Stoos.

Tip: The peak experience ticket [https://www.stoos.ch/en/pages/planen-buchen] is the ideal way to discover the Stoos area. Hikers, walkers and connoisseurs can use all cable cars and mountain railways in the area without restrictions for one day. For families, children with the SBB junior travelcard or children’s co-travelcard can travel for free. 

Altitude: 1,922m Accessibility: Take the train to Schwyz, bus via Schwyz (centre) to Schwyz (Schwyz, Stoosbahn) and funicular to Stoos; or train to Brunnen, bus to Morschach (Morschach, Luftseilbahn) and cable car to Stoos; chair lifts to the Fronalpstock and the Klingenstock Views: The two Mythen peaks, Glarus, Uri Alps and Reuss Valley, Lake Lucerne and Rigi Attractions: Ridge hike from the Klingenstock to the Fronalpstock, summit walks on the Fronalpstock, the Stoos moorlands, Little Stoos Lake and the surrounding area Winter: Stoos-Fronalpstock and Klingenstock winter sports resort Special highlight: A visit to the Alpine restaurant (Laui Alpine Farm), ride on the steepest funicular in the world
The Swiss Travel Pass covers the entire fare as far as Stoos. Buy your mountain railway ticket for the Fronalpstock on site.


DAY TRIPS TO THE MOUNTAINS
Buy your return mountain railway return tickets now

Timetable and tickets [https://www.sbb.ch/de/kaufen/pages/fahrplan/fahrplan.xhtml?nach=Fronalpstock]

data.name: Life on the high pastures.
data.abstract: Enjoy a hike with a special ingredient. Explore the trails in connection with the alpine cheese dairies in Lake Lucerne Region. Visit the dairies and taste their wares, including fried cheese or goat cheese. Then relax comfortably in alpine taverns. If you want to visit a cheese dairy with a few friends or in a group, contact the dairy in advance. Guided tours are only available upon request.
data.description: The popular Walenpfad trail from Bannalp to Engelberg is known as one of Switzerland’s most beautiful high-altitude hikes. Along the way the walk passes through Alp Oberfeld, home to a cluster of wooden houses where organic farmers spend the summer with their goats, cows and other animals. You can stop here for one or more days, sampling life up on the high pastures among dramatic mountain scenery. Eat fresh, typical alpine cuisine; spend a night in the dormitory in the converted barn, or in the simple but elegant panelled suite; and join in with whatever work needs doing on the farm. You can also help make the delicious mountain cheese – and see how much work goes into this local delicacy.

data.name: Swiss Holiday Park
data.abstract: High above Lake Lucerne, in Morschach, lies the Swiss Holiday Park. The largest holidays and leisure resort in Switzerland leaves nothing to be desired with its huge range of offers.
data.description:
Dive into the fun. The Swiss Holiday Park offers fun for the whole family. In the separate toddler area, the little ones can let off steam on children's slides and with water games. Connoisseur children and adults can enjoy the indoor and outdoor pools, float through the white water channel or whizz down the water slides.

There is also plenty of relaxation in the water park: the whirlpool and massage loungers are perfect for relaxing. Whether it's massages, cosmetic and wellness treatments, the Roman-Irish spa establishment or the spacious sauna area - you'll find everything here that's good for you.

Getting here by public transport: Take the train or boat to Brunnen and continue by bus to the Swiss Holiday Park

data.name: By ship on the slope
data.abstract: Only in Lucerne. From the pier near Lucerne railway station, guests can travel directly to the Klewenalp Stockhütte ski area by boat. This one-hour trip is a chance to enjoy some amazing views of Lake Lucerne.
data.description:
By boat is undoubtedly also one of the most comfortable ways to travel to the piste, especially when not carrying any cumbersome ski equipment – as this can be rented right by the piste for CHF 30 (ski/snowboard, sticks and ski boots). It is not just skiers and snowboarders who will love this boat service – winter hikers and tobogganing fans will find much to delight them on the Klewenalp as well. 

More information [https://www.tellpass.ch]

data.name: Culinary Cheese Hikes
data.abstract: Listen to the ringing of cowbells, breathe in the fresh mountain air, feel lush grass under your feet, gaze at the most beautiful valleys of the Lake Lucerne Region, and taste homemade cheese specialties in a cozy alpine pub. This is hiking with all five senses.
data.description:
Throughout the summer, traditional Alpine dairies by the side of enjoyable hiking trails in the Lake Lucerne region attract visitors. Enjoy delicious kinds of cheeses, such as alpine, fried or goat, and relaxing moments in cozy alpine pubs. 

Niederrickenbach is the ideal starting point in the hiking paradise of Maria-Rickenbach. From Dallenwil you ascend with the old-timer aerial cable car to the Musenalp. There you will find the Alpine Dairy Musenalp, where not only the cheese but also the view is sensational. The Alpine Dairy Bleiki, which one passes on the 1-hour hike down to the valley, also welcomes hikers who want to make some purchases. 

A somewhat longer tour starts at the Älggialp, Switzerland’s geographic center, where a circular trail leads through pristine nature and to an alpine dairy at a lake called Sachsler Seefeldsee. The hiking time is about three hours. 
Group tours in alpine dairies are arranged upon request

data.name: Alpine flower trail around the Klewenstock
data.abstract: The southern shore of Lake Lucerne in Nidwalden canton is served by several cable railways all year. The mountain stations, at heights of 1000 meters above the lake, afford superb views.
data.description:
Just 3 km long, the route around the Klewenstock (Alpine flower trail) is ideal for leisure walkers, families with prams and Alpine flower aficionados. Depending on the season, up to 120 different Alpine flowers (some of them very rare) are indicated by signs on a 700-meter stretch. Most of them grow here naturally.

The signs are changed regularly to match the locations of the plants. Alois Käslin (of Bärglers Weysl), a local, is responsible for maintenance. 

The circular walk starts by Klewenalp mountain station (cable car from Beckenried) and passes the chapel to reach the cosy Alpstubli mountain restaurant and Rötenport; then it veers left, rising gently southwards around the Klewenstock.

data.name: Mountain Railway Trips to Mt. Rigi
data.abstract: With breathtaking 360-degree panoramic views, the Rigi offers a first-class mountain experience whatever the season. The cog railways from Goldau and Vitznau, as well as the cable car from Weggis, enable a variety of round trips, which can also be combined with a boat trip on Lake Lucerne.
data.description:
As the first mountain railway in Europe, it has been transporting guests comfortably from Vitznau up to the impressive heart of the mountains since 1871. During the 30-minute ascent by cog railway to almost 1,800m above sea level, visitors can enjoy spectacular views over the lake landscape, passing grazing cows, traditional farms and colourful wildflower meadows.

From spring 2022, the historic fleet will be joined by new vehicles. The design of these new trains pays homage to the world’s oldest cog railcar, No. 6, from 1911, which still regularly plies the line between Goldau and Rigi Kulm. The choice of the smart white and bronze colour scheme gives the new carriages a timeless look and forges a link to the service’s origins as the first mountain railway in Europe.

While the current fleet uses the braking energy generated when travelling downhill to heat the carriages, the new trains will feed this power back into their own network as electricity, saving resources for the uphill journey. Rigi Railways are thus taking another big step towards greater sustainability [https://www.rigi.ch/en/about-us/sustainable]. 

This unique railway adventure on the Rigi, combining Europe’s first historic mountain railway and modern train technology, is the only one of its kind in the world.

More information [https://www.rigi.ch/en]


GENERAL INFORMATION ABOUT THE RIGI
Altitude: 1,798m above sea level How to get there: By boat or bus to Vitznau, then by cog railway to Rigi Kulm. By train or bus to Arth-Goldau, then by cog railway to Rigi Kulm. By boat or bus to Weggis, then by cable car to Rigi Kaltbad. Timetable: Runs all year round Journey time: From Vitznau it takes just 32 minutes to reach Rigi Kulm, 39 minutes to Rigi Kulm from Goldau, 10 minutes from Weggis to Rigi Kaltbad, where there is a connection to the cog railway to Rigi Kulm Attractions: 360-degree panoramic view from the summit, special steam-driven excursions, mineral baths & Rigi Kaltbad spa Food and drink: Choice of around 30 mountain inns Special note: Fully included in the Swiss Travel Pass scheme
Book your Tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/] BROCHURE
 Download exciting and extensive information about the Rigi, featuring highlights along with key facts and figures, here:
PDF brochures [https://shop.rigi.ch/en/pages/brochures-prospectus]


DAY TRIPS TO THE MOUNTAINS

Timetable and tickets [https://www.sbb.ch/en/buying/pages/fahrplan/fahrplan.xhtml]

data.name: Excursion: Mountain Climbing, Mt. Pilatus and Mt. Titlis
data.abstract: Ascending one of Central Switzerland's alpine peaks is an easy day trip from Lucerne.
data.description: Mt. Pilatus (7,000 feet high and home to the world's steepest cogwheel railway) and Mt. Titlis (at 10,000 feet, central Switzerland's highest peak) are two of the region's most popular climbs. Bus or train transport carries visitors along the shores of Lake Lucerne to a cable car, which whisks riders up to the top. The reward is a sweeping view of snowy, purple mountain peaks and the meandering Lake Lucerne.

data.name: Fast descent with the Bikeboard
data.abstract: When the summer season approaches, the first fast bikeboard ride is kicked off. The trendy sports equipment is simple to handle and guarantees an exciting adventure.
data.description:
The 6-seater gondola lift whisks you from Emmetten to the lofty height of the Stockhütte. Here, you can rent a bikeboard, put on a helmet and off you go, zipping down into the valley. If you can’t get enough of it, simply ride up again. The wonderful view over the Lucerne Region and Lake Lucerne makes the excursion a special experience. 
The bikeboard rental is inside the mountain station of the Emmetten-Stockhütte gondola lift. Length of the route: 5.7 km

data.name: Hammetschwand lift and Felsenweg path
data.abstract: The 152.8 meter-high lift to the Bürgenstock looks like a heaven-bound rocket. And views from Hammetschwand over Lucerne and its lake are best described as heavenly!
data.description:
Warning! Before you make the trip, check if the Felsenweg and the Hammetschwand Lift are open. Find more information here [https://www.felsenweg.ch/].

The Felsenweg path begins in the middle of the Bürgenstock Resort, between the chapel and Parisa – Persian Cuisine. Along the path, twelve panels tell the impressive story of the Bürgenstock Resort. Over 150 years ago, two visionary friends, Bucher and Durrer, discovered the Bürgenberg and soon opened the first hotel. Their boundless pioneering spirit led to extraordinary technical achievements: the first funicular railway in Switzerland, the highest and fastest open-air lift in Europe, a revolutionary hydroelectric power plant, and the Felsenweg path itself. A story full of success, innovation, and incredible visions – don't miss this truly breathtaking story. All information is available via mobile phone.

The lift along the rock face has been the fastest way to the "highest viewpoint in the city of Lucerne" since the beginning of the last century: from the valley station inside the rock, it takes just under a minute to reach fresh air again. In the summer, the lift tower is illuminated at night and is easily visible from Lucerne. From Hammetschwand (already in the canton of Nidwalden), hiking trails lead back to the Bürgenstock Resort on Lake Lucerne, or you can return via the "Känzeli" along the Felsenweg path.

Altitude: 1128m 
Accessibility: 
In summer, there are 3 boat connections from Lucerne to Kehrsiten-Bürgenstock; connection with the Bürgenstock bahn from the lake to the Bürgenstock Resort on Lake Lucerne; from Stansstad, take the postbus to Bürgenstock (groups must reserve their journey with the postbus in advance); the Felsenweg path leads to the valley station of the Hammetschwand lift (only in summer).
View: Over the Lake Lucerne "Kreuztrichter", Rigi, Mythen, Buochserhorn, Stanserhorn, Pilatus and Brünig Pass and Bernese Alps in the background 
Attractions: The scenic Felsenweg path offers in-depth views over the lake across to the extraordinary lift 
Culinary aspects: Taverne 1879, Verbena Restaurant and Bärgbeizli Hammetschwand 
Overnight stays: 3 hotels in the Bürgenstock Resort on Lake Lucerne (ranging from 3* to 5* Superior) 
Winter: The Felsenweg path, Hammetschwand lift and Bärgbeizli Hammetschwand are not open in winter

data.name: Historical route by canoe
data.description: The trip to the ship trading route of the old Swiss starts in the harbor of Brunnen. The visitors paddle their canoe across Lake Lucerne and stop to visit the site where Switzerland was founded: the Rütli. The excursion is guided by an expert and lasts two hours at most.

data.name: Ride the dragon to Mount Pilatus
data.abstract: It may not breathe fire, but it’s still hot: the “Dragon Ride” aerial cableway whizzes from Fräkmüntegg straight to Pilatus Kulm, over 2,132 m above sea level.
data.description:
The “Dragon Ride” has a cockpit-like design and an almost fully glazed exterior, so it feels just like flying as you enjoy the views of Lake Lucerne and the surrounding Alps on the 3.5-minute ride. You can continue the experience by using a special vehicle for the return journey from Fräkmüntegg; ride down the slopes to Krienseregg on a snowbike, choosing a blue or red piste depending on your skill level.
Dragon Ride [http://www.pilatus.ch/en/railway-cableways/aerial-cableway/]

data.name: Sunny slope
data.abstract: Views at the start of this sunny piste extend over ten Swiss lakes and vertically down to the Rütli meadow; spectacular to say the least, with the majority of wide and easy slopes also offering a glimpse of the Mythen mountain range as you make your way down.
data.description:
At the Stoos heights, winter sports enthusiasts find versatile slopes, fast sledding and airboard fun, scenic cross country trails, diverse winter hiking and snowshoe trails, along with many a cosy mountain hut. The start to these broad and sunny pistes lies at 1922 m on the Fronalpstock summit, which is conveniently reached with the comfortable 4-seater chairlift. And on reaching the top you have beautiful views over Lake Lucerne, the Schwyz basin and Mythen mountains. Separate sledding and airboard runs bid fast fun aside the same slopes - and from the middle Mettlen station you spot the idyllic car-free mountain village of Stoos. Rock bottom, at the valley station of the chairlift, two cosy restaurants, kid’s ski country (Kinderskiland) with magic carpet and a sports store with possible rentals also please all. 
Starting point: Fronalpstock Gipfel (1922 m a.s.l.)

Accessibility of starting point: chairlift

Destination: Stoos (1320 m a.s.l.)

Length: 6.5 km

Altitude difference: 600 Meter

Gradient: 25% (average), 60% (maximum)

Level of difficulty: intermediate (normal slope)

Food and beverages: at the start, on the way, at the finish (Gipfelrestaurant Fronalpstock, Pistenrestaurant Welesch, Restaurant Alpstubli & Restaurant zum Pasta Gadä)

data.name: Wirzweli tin toboggan
data.abstract: What sounds like distant thunder soon turns out to be toboggans hurtling down the 535-m-long tin toboggan run.
data.description:
Even just watching and egging on the riders is an unforgettable experience. The tin toboggan goes through the "Wirzweli Zauberland", which is a kind of giant adventure playground and family barbecue area. The petting zoo boasts dwarf bunnies, ducks, geese and bleating goats. And the herd of Shetland ponies will soon have little girls' hearts beating faster.
The views of Lake Lucerne, the Stanserhorn and Rigi are truly magnificent.

data.name: Funicular, cliff walk and mechanical lifton the Bürgenstock
data.abstract: The funicular, cliff walk and mechanical lift on the Bürgenstock represent a triple tribute to the art and technology of the belle époque. The Bürgenstock Bahn, built in 1888, is the oldest electric funicular railway in Switzerland.
data.description:
The panoramic cliff walk, meanwhile, has been described as “the most beautiful mountain promenade in the world”. From 1900 to 1905, its creators blasted and tunnelled their way through the rock to create a spectacular path 2.5 kilometres long, 500 metres above Lake Lucerne. The year of its completion also saw the open ing of the Hammetschwand Lift. The highest outdoor elevator in Europe travels through the rock and up an elegant tower in just under a minute, offering thrilling and giddying views on its way to the panoramic lookout point at the top of the Bürgenstock plateau, the Hammetschwand (1,132m a.s.l.).
Open: Cliff walk and lift: approx. May to Oct. 
Due for completion in 2017 Central Switzerland is witnessing the emergence of a premier resort – the Bürgenstock Resort. Therefore the Bürgenstock Bahn is closed.

data.name: Waking up high above the lake
data.description: Guests begin their day waking at 2,132m, looking out over Lake Lucerne. Onwards with the gamekeeper on a journey to discover the flora and fauna of the mountain. With a little luck, the group will catch a glimpse of ibex colonies on the Pilatus mountain massif. This will be followed by a hearty brunch to recover and reflect on the amazing adventure.

data.name: Cable car adventures - with a difference
data.abstract: The cable cars in the canton of Uri achieve a combined total ascent of 23,000 metres. Many of the 36 or so small cars are open to the elements, and sometimes there is only space for four people per journey.
data.description:
The canton of Uri is a dream destination for cable car aficionados. Travelling in the open wooden cars admittedly takes a bit of courage, but it’s worth it: connoisseurs will enjoy the panoramic terraces above the Reusstal valley, Lake Lucerne and the Schächental valley. 

Originally built to reach Alpine farms, the cable cars are serviced and checked on a regular basis. The upper stations are the starting point for some great high-altitude hikes.

INFORMATION
Altitude: 786 – 2,961 metres 
How to get there: 
Some valley stations can be reached by bus, some only on foot or by car
Please note: Some of the cable cars are operated with coins or tokens, meaning that users are not tied to timetables. Tokens are available from restaurants and some private houses 
Views: The valleys and the mountains of Uri, for example the Clariden, Windgällen, Rophaien, Bristen, Spannort and Uri Rotstock 
Attractions: Riding in the open wooden cars sometimes takes a little courage, but it’s worth it: just follow the instructions and it’ll be plain sailing 
Food and drink: Mountain inns such as Weid, Alpstubli Selez, Biel-Kinzig, Spilau/Lidernenhütte, Gitschenen, Brüsti, Golzeren or by the Arnisee lake 
Accommodation: Simple accommodation is often available in the mountain inns 
Groups: Some of the small cable cars can only carry a limited number of passengers per hour; big groups are advised to consider larger cable cars such as that serving the Gemsstock (Andermatt) instead 
Winter: Many of the cable cars operate in winter

data.name: Adventure Mountain Sonnenberg
data.abstract: The Sonnenberg cogwheel train, called the “Little Blue Train,” whisks visitors in a few minutes to the multifaceted adventure mountain near Kriens, a leisure paradise and recreational area.
data.description: The Sonnenberg (700 meters above sea level) is the “small” local mountain to the north of Kriens. Due to its southern exposure, the Sonnenberg’s name, “Sun Mountain”, is certainly justified. The nostalgic train, which is over 100 years old, starts in the heart of Kriens and ascends the Sonnenberg, where visitors find a diverse leisure program: Vitaparcours (exercise trail), children’s playgrounds, walking paths and many picnic spots with barbeque pits. In the midst of this fascinating, almost untouched nature, visitors can enjoy the imposing panoramic view of the mountains, Lake Lucerne, Kriens and the Greater Lucerne area.

data.name: Funicular Treib-Seelisberg
data.abstract: The funicular takes guests from the Treib landing stage in 8 minutes to the Seelisberg plateau, a popular vantage point. The mountain station is located on the “Swiss Path” leading to Rütli or Bauen. A variety of sights can be reached from the station in no time at all. The Treib–Seelisberg train connects with the PostBus to Beckenried/Stans.
data.description:
Already in the 16th century Seelisberg was visited by pilgrims, then followed the tourists of the 19th and 20th century, which included many a crowned head. The view from this promontory overlooking Lake Lucerne is mind-boggling. Visitors come to Treib where they take the funicular, installed in 1916, that brings them up the mountain to Seelisberg.
Today, this nostalgic journey holds a special treat at dusk: the funicular is slowed down and as it inches down the mountain, fondue is served on the little tables between the banquettes. An accordion player plays old tunes and the view is just as romantic as can be as one slowly descends towards the valley's lights. After coffee and dessert is served on the terrace of the Hotel Treib, the funicular once again ascends to Seelisberg.
For groups of 10-25 persons daily beyond the scheduled timing . Reservations mandatory.

data.name: Hiking on Mount Pilatus
data.abstract: Lucerne’s Pilatus mountain (2,118m above sea level) boasts some of the most spectacular views in Switzerland. From the summit, you can see across the Central Swiss Alps and the Jura all the way to France and the Black Forest in Germany.
data.description:
Pilatus is one of the most accessible peaks in the Swiss Alps, which means hikers can pick and choose the best trails for them and leave the effort of the ascent to the various cable cars. Pilatus can be reached by gondola and cable car from Lucerne, while the steepest cog railway in the world takes visitors up from Alpnachstad. Once at the top, there are several well-developed trails leading to the various panoramic peaks. Where dragons once breathed fire and ghosts howled, families and visitors from all around the world now walk on secure cliff paths. 

Peak tour – Pilatus Kulm to Esel, Oberhaupt and Tomlishorn

From the Pilatus Kulm upper station, the Esel, Oberhaupt and Tomlishorn viewpoints are a short walk away along good footpaths. It takes 20 minutes to walk round the Oberhaupt peak, 15 minutes to climb the Esel and 30 to 40 minutes to reach the highest, outermost Pilatus peak, the Tomlishorn.

Fräkmüntegg and Krienseregg

This easy yet scenic hike (1 hour 40 mins) goes from Krienseregg [https://www.pilatus.ch/entdecken/krienseregg/]middle station past the Schönenboden hut to Fräkmüntegg [https://www.pilatus.ch/entdecken/fraekmuentegg/] middle station. Families and adventure junkies will welcome the opportunity to combine the hike with Switzerland’s longest summer toboggan run and suspension rope park on the Fräkmüntegg. There is also a big children’s playground as well as various BBQ spots and picnic sites.

Drachenweg (Dragon trail)


TheDrachenweg [https://www.pilatus.ch/entdecken/drachenweg/] trail atop Mount Pilatus is a chance for young and old to discover the myths and legends associated with this mountain. This 40-minute circular trail offers glorious views of the Central Swiss Alps and Lake Lucerne.

Alpnachstad – Pilatus Kulm


For those who prefer to tackle the ascent up Pilatus from Alpnachstad under their own steam rather than by cog railway, the medium-difficulty hike via Ämsigen is a great choice. This route takes 4 hours 30 minutes and leads past flower-filled alpine meadows, burbling mountain streams and steep rocky cliffs. The effort of the climb is rewarded with a spectacular descent to the valley by cog railway – with an incline of 48%, it remains the steepest cog railway in the world.

Other hiking routes and information on Pilatus [https://www.pilatus.ch/entdecken/wandern-am-pilatus/]

Tip:

Fancy catching a sunset up the mountain? Two major hotels run excursions to enable visitors to enjoy atmospheric sunrises and sunsets on top of the world.

data.name: Fatbiking
data.abstract: Biking is no longer only possible during the warm seasons. Winter has been taken over by the new trend «fatbiking», which offers great training opportunities for active people as well as leisurely rides for pleasure seekers. The over-sized tires make riding on snow a safe and fun adventure.
data.description:
Fatbikes, or snowbikes, were developed in North America around 10 years ago. They were constructed to glide over the snow without sinking in. Fatbikes have massive tires and are ridden with very little pressure. They are ideal for difficult terrain such as snow, sand, sludge, and mud. After having become very popular in the snow and sand deserts of the USA, especially in Alaska and New Mexico, these bikes are at the moment conquering Switzerland as well. 

Here's a list of destinations which offer fatbiking: 

Bernese Oberland
 * Gstaad & Zweisimmen: Fatbiking Region Gstaad [https://www.gstaad.ch/en/winter/outdoor/winterbike.html]

Graubünden
 * Davos Klosters: Fatbiking Davos [https://www.davos.ch/en/activities/snowsports/fatbiking-on-pischa]
 * St.Moritz: Fatbiking St.Moritz [https://www.engadin.ch/en/activities/-115348/]

Lucerne – Lake Lucerne Region
 * Andermatt: Fatbiking Andermatt [https://www.andermatt.ch/event/gaesteprogramm-fatbike-adventure-by-night-97cd926c5a]
 * Melchsee-Frutt: Fatbiking Melchsee-Frutt [http://www.melchsee-frutt.ch/en/summer/scooter-and-bike-riding/fatbike-plausch/]

Valais * Obergoms: Fatbiking Obergoms [https://www.goms.ch/en/fatbike]
 * Zermatt: Fatbike Night-Ride [https://www.zermatt.ch/en/Media/Tickets/Fatbike-Night-Ride]

Lake Geneva Region:

 * Villars: Fakebike Bretaye-Villars Track [https://www.villars-diablerets.ch/en/V1297/bretaye-villars-track?group=5]

data.name: Snowshoe hiking on Pilatus
data.abstract: Three signposted snowshoe trails link Krienseregg and Fräkmüntegg. These routes are all classed as easy, making them suitable for families and snowshoe beginners alike.
data.description:
Krienseregg-Gibelegg-Dorschnei-Krienseregg
This circular hike takes just under two hours to complete and offers glorious views over the city of Lucerne and Lake Lucerne. If you fancy a delicious snack along the way, we recommend stopping at Berghaus Dorschnei.

Fräkmüntegg-Bonere-Mülimäs-Gibelegg-Krienseregg
Starting from Kriens, snowshoe hikers can take a cable car to Fräkmüntegg. The trail to Krienseregg takes one and a half hours to complete, with just one gentle ascent. Hikers can stop off at Berghaus Rickenschwändi to boost their energy levels.

Fräkmüntegg-Bonern-Rehlöcher-Fräkmüntegg
This circular trail can be completed in a morning and features moderate ascents, making it ideal for the whole family. The route boasts panoramic views of Lucerne, Lake Lucerne and the Pre-Alps. At the end of the trail, head into Restaurant Fräkmüntegg to enjoy a hot chocolate or a cup of coffee.

More information [https://www.pilatus.ch/entdecken/schneeschuhlaufen/]

data.name: A hike to Fluonalp by sunrise
data.abstract: A ride in a cable car, a legendary hiking trail, a summit at sunrise and a rustic mountain hut where you can even make Alpine cheese – the perfect mountain hike experience awaits on the Fluonalp above Lake Lungern!
data.description:
The worthwhile two-day hike starts at the upper station of the Lungern-Turren cable car. At the beginning, the route follows the butterfly path [https://www.schweizmobil.ch/de/wanderland/routen/route-0575.html]. More than 115 types of diurnal large butterflies live here in the most species-rich butterfly region in Switzerland.

You reach the Fluonalp after a short descent. It is surrounded by lush alpine pastures bordered by the nature and wildlife reserve below the Giswilerstock. There is a wonderful view here over Lake Sarnen across to Pilatus, the Rigi and Lake Lucerne.

The rustic mountain hut Fluonalp [https://www.fluonalp.ch/] offers simple overnight accommodation in cosy multi-bed rooms. Local connoisseurs recommend the house speciality «Hindersimagronen” from the menu. Key info: You can visit the Alpine dairy. You can even make your own cheese if you arrange this in advance.

On the second day, it takes about one hour to reach the Giswilerstock early in the morning (1,824m). The sunrise and the panoramic view of the Central Swiss Alps are ample reward for the early climb. After a hearty Alpine breakfast on the Fluonalp, you’ll have plenty of energy for the walk back through the Sädel and Ägerten forests to the Lungern-Turren cable car.

data.name: Lorelei bathing islands by the Reuss Delta
data.abstract: On hot summer days, you can get a real South Pacific feeling in sleepy Flüelen: that’s the best time to visit the “Lorelei” bathing islands on Lake Uri.
data.description:
Things looked bad for the Uri Reuss Delta until the early eighties: metre by metre, the shoreline was disappearing into the lake. Thanks to the Reuss Delta Act of 1985, a balance has been found between moderate gravel extraction, natural habitats and shallow water areas for flora and fauna as well as touristic use.

Replenished by 3.3 million tonnes of rock from the Gotthard railway base tunnel, the small group of islands is one of the major attractions in and around Lake Lucerne. On hot summer days in particular, you can get a real South Pacific feeling on the “Lorelei” bathing islands. Large, flat rocks provide an ideal place to sunbathe and linger a while with friends – the largest block comes from the Gotthard Base Tunnel and is a reminder of the material’s origin. Fine sand covers the coarse tunnel gravel of the bathing islands, which can only be reached by swimming across. Out of consideration for the flora and fauna of the Reuss Delta, only the Lorelei islands and the designated bathing areas may be used.

It costs nothing to swim in the Reuss Delta, and sanitary facilities such as toilet blocks and outdoor showers are available.

Getting there: By train or boat to Flüelen, no parking available.

data.name: Lake Zug Cruises
data.abstract: Right at the very heart of Central Switzerland, shared by cantons Zug, Schwyz and Lucerne, lies Lake Zug - Switzerland’s tenth largest lake.
data.description:
Surrounded by lovely hills, this picturesque region offers a great variety of hiking, biking and skating trails. All of these can be perfectly combined with a culinary excursion on Lake Zug, for example on the Sushi Cruise, the Dessert Cruise or the Crêpes Cruise.

FACTS
Route: Zug – Arth
Distance: Length of the lake 13.7 km
Duration: approx. 1h
EXCURSION TIPS
 * Zugerberg – magnificent view onto mountains and lakes 
 * Animal Park Goldau – wild animals up close on 34 hectares of natural habitat 
 * Höllgrotten Baar – a unique stalactite cave with fairytale dropstone formations 
 * Einsiedeln Monastery – home of roughly 50 monks
 * Aeschbach Chocolatier 

FOOD & BEVERAGES
Catering services available in the boat restaurants.TIMETABLE
Lake Zug Cruises operate from April to October.
All connections here [https://www.zugersee-schifffahrt.ch/en/scheduled-cruises-travel-info/timetable/]TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]
RESERVATIONS
No seat reservation required – free seating.

data.name: Mount Pilatus Cogwheel Train and Cable Car
data.abstract: Easily accessible by public transport from Lucerne, Mount Pilatus is the ideal adventure mountain for the entire family.
data.description:
The world’s steepest cog railway starts its climb at Alpnachstad and tackles a maximum gradient of 48 percent, thereby passing forests, meadows and rock faces. On the north side, a gondola cableway and an aerial cableway connect Kriens to Pilatus Kulm.

With the new aerial cableway Dragon Ride, guests are practically flying up to Pilatus. It takes the cableway a mere 3.5 minutes to reach Pilatus (2,132 m a.s.l.) from the intermediate station Fräkmüntegg (1,416 m a.s.l.). Thanks to spacious seating, a cockpit-like structure and large windows, the cableway offers a unique view of Lucerne and its lake.INFORMATION
Altitude: 2,132 m a.s.l.
Arrival: Bus number 1 from Lucerne Station to Kriens / Zentrum Pilatus


Gondola from Kriens (Lucerne) via Krienseregg to Fräkmuntegg, aerial cableway to Pilatus Kulm or cog railway (only during summer) from Alpnachstad (boat or train from Lucerne) to Pilatus Kulm

Timetable: Operates year-round, although the cogwheel train operates only during the summer season.
Travel duration to summit: 40 mins
Attractions: Rock trail and secure tracks to Oberhaupt, Esel and Tomlishorn; rope park and summer toboggan run Fräkmüntegg
Food & beverage: Evening summit rendezvous in summer (from Alpnachstad), Restaurant Krienseregg and Restaurant Chalet, Hotel Pilatus-Kulm
Specials: The world’s steepest cog railway from Alpnachstad to Pilatus (48% gradient), spectacular passage “Eselwand”.
Reduced rate mountain rail ascent with the Swiss Travel Pass/GA travelcard. Buy your tickets on arrival at the station. More information here [https://www.pilatus.ch/en/]

data.name: Zentralbahn
data.abstract: The Zentralbahn connects Lucerne and Engelberg, passing through Stans and also runs between Lucerne and Interlaken East (see GoldenPass Line) passing by Sarnen and the Brünig Pass.
data.description:
Routes:
Lucerne - Stans - Engelberg (- Titlis)
Lucerne - Sarnen - Brünig - Meiringen - Interlaken East

In a bit less than an hour, the Zentralbahn brings you from Lucerne with its glittering lake to the fascinating Alpine world of Engelberg, home to one of Switzerland's famous cloisters. 

Getting there is half the fun and so it is with this trip that goes through many charming villages and unique vista points. 

Option: Ascend Mount Titlis with the world's first rotating cable car. Once there, admire the glacier and the grandiose alpine panorama from an altitude of 3020 m a.s.l. or visit the Ice Grotto, the Glacier Park, enjoy a ride on the chair-lift «Ice Flyer» or test your mettle on a «Trottibike». 


BRÜNIG SAFARI AND LIVEGUIDE

Brünig Safari [http://www.zentralbahn.ch/en/node/70]From May until October, you can discover 13 native wild animals – made from wood! They are positioned in their natural environments along the Giswil – Meiringen line so as to be visible from the train. The Brünig Safari flyer contains interesting and unusual details about the animals and their lifestyles.

LiveGuide [http://www.zentralbahn.ch/en/node/322] Thanks to the multimedia LiveGuide app, travellers obtain background information on the Zentralbahn, the route and the most fascinating sights along the way. A short film also shows the loveliest points on the route from the driver's vantage point.

data.name: Golden Roundtrip Pilatus
data.abstract: The landmark of Central Switzerland, and Lucerne's 'own' peak: Mount Pilatus. The Golden Tour by steamer, red rack-and-pinion railway and back via cable railways is the classic round trip.
data.description:
One excursion with five means of transport! Sail from Lucerne to Alpnachstad on the 'Unterwalden' steamship or on a motor vessel. Then comes the world's steepest rack-and-pinion railway up to Pilatus Kulm (2073 m a.s.l.). The 'Locher system' toothed rack and the special track switch at the mountain station are unique. 

Enjoy the view of the lake, the mountains, and the city of Lucerne. Take a walk through the rock gallery, or hike to the Tomlishorn where you can savor a delicious snack in the restaurant. A spectacular ride by aerial cable car «Dragon Ride» and panorama gondola down to Kriens concludes this tour. Return to Lucerne by bus.

data.name: Hallwilersee
data.abstract: Visitors here can look forward to a romantic landscape, the enchanting Hallwyl moated castle with its impressive exhibition and the Lake Hallwil navigation company, more than 100 years old, which entertains its guests aboard five motor launches.
data.description:
Like the Baldeggersee lake a little further south, Lake Hallwil is located in the Seetal, a north-south valley that leads from the Lucerne hinterland to Lenzburg. The shores around Lake Hallwil must not be built on - thus presenting a most attractive trail around the lake and an impressive natural landscape. Few kilometers don’t lead directly along the waters’ edge, as the reed zones are under protection in the form of nature reserve. 

Bathing beaches around the lake are tempting places to cool off. Many of them offer a wide range of water sports. Some of the landing stages offer the chance to combine the 20km circular hike around the lake with a boat trip - and a cruise on the Lake of Hallwil is a guaranteed joyful experience.

In addition to the scheduled boat service, there are also special tours such as Sunday brunch trips, a gourmet ride or a Father Christmas trip. Wedding excursions are also popular because of the romantic setting. SUNSET:

Sunset: Enjoy a fantastic evening atmosphere in Meisterschwanden on the eastern lakeshore. You can celebrate the romantic mood over dinner at the Seerose or Delphin restaurants.

data.name: Herzschlaufe Seetal
data.abstract: The tour «Herzschlaufe Seetal» leads from Eschenbach LU to Lenzburg and back for over nearly 120 km, all this away from traffic. The attractive E-bike route can be done in two days and shows an unfamiliar area of the cantons of Aargau and Lucerne.
data.description:
Start of tour:Eschenbach LU End of tour:Eschenbach LU Number of stages:2Length:114 km Asphalted:76 km Natural surface:38 km Demanding physical fitness:difficult Difference in altitude:↑ 2150 m
↓ 2150 m 
During the first day of the trip, the «Herzschlaufe Seetal» passes the monastery Eschenbach right after the beginning. The route then changes into small paths, where cyclists are surrounded by high trunk cultures. Soon it is possible to get to the »Johanniterkommende Hohenrain«, with stunning views over the Alps and Lake Baldegg.

The route becomes steeper and steeper and slowly leads over the Lindenberg. On top of the secluded plateau, the Horben Castle with chapel and farm suprises the guests. After a brief passage in the forest, the height route begins. Cyclists will go through pretty villages and generous landscape and enjoy the view of Lake Hallwil.

Again they will be surprised by a castle (Hilfikon), which traps visitors with its noble sphere in an unexpected place. Trough a forest you'll get to Seengen and will soon see the great moated castle Hallwyl. You'll only get a glimpse of the tourist hustle, then the route disappears in the cozy forest and follows the lively Aabach river direction Lenzburg.

Starting from proud city of Lenzburg and the neighboring Staufen, the quiet path finds a loophole just after Seon, which results in a magical forest. At the end of the wood the Liebegg castle appears as if in a dream. The track once again disappears in the green of the Aargau area and reappears only on the top of Bööler, where you overlook the vast land.

A schuss leads to Schlossrued. Thereafter, a ridge has to be climbed again, where you'll cycle for long periods without seeing villages or traffic. Only in Beromünster you'll be back to known locations and will be able to enjoy the magnificent Landflecklein.

The route leads back away from traffic and to the golf court Sempachersee, where you can take a break and enjoy the magnificent views of Mount Pilatus. Shortly afterwards, the loop joins the regional routes 94 and 99 (Heart Route). From here it is only a short hop to Eschenbach.
www.herzschlaufe-seetal.ch [http://www.herzschlaufe-seetal.ch/]

data.name: Homberg Observation Tower
data.abstract: The Homberg overlooks the Seetal region and the adjacent Wynental valley. The views of snow-capped peaks, green pastures and deep blue lakes from the top of the tower are magnificent.
data.description: The Homberg observation tower is 17 meters high and offers views in southern direction of the Oberwynental in Canton Aargau and the Michelsamt in Canton Lucerne. Lakes Hallwil and Baldegg as well as the chain of the eastern Alps with Mt. Säntis are visible in the east. To the west are Stierenberg, the western Alps and the western part of the Jura mountain range. In winter the tower is frequently drenched in bright sunlight high above a sea of fog. The nearby rustic Homberg inn with its generous terrace and fun children's playground is a lovely place to linger. The Homberg is a popular destination for day trips and easy to reach by passenger boat across Lake Hallwil or by the Seetal and Wynental railways.

data.name: Titlis
data.abstract: The journey to the Titlis is truly an adventure in itself. First take the Titlis Xpress gondola to the middle station, then continue your journey in the TITLIS Rotair, the world’s first revolving cable car, all the way to the top.
data.description:
At 3,062 metres, the summit offers not only a breathtaking 360° panorama of the wide Engelberg valley but also a view straight down into the abyss, with countless crevasses carved into the glacial ice.

Things get really cool at the upper station, where a 150-metre-long artificial glacier cave cuts straight into the heart of the Titlis Glacier. The ceiling is covered in ice crystals, the glacial ice shimmers a mysterious blue, and crevasses open up in the roof. If you’re thinking of stepping inside the ice, be sure to wrap up warm, as the temperature under the 20-metre-thick glacier never gets above -1°C! 

There are a host of fun activities on top of the glacier, too, such as the Ice Flyer glacier chairlift or the glacier park. Crossing the glacier and climbing to the summit is a special experience – naturally only under the supervision of a mountain guide.INFORMATION
Altitude: 3,062 metres above sea level
How to get there: Zentralbahn railway from Lucerne to Engelberg, walk to the valley station, gondola and cable car to the top of the Titlis
Timetable: Runs all year round
Journey time: Around 30 minutes to the summit
Attractions & activities: Glacier cave [https://www.titlis.ch/en/activities/glacier-cave], “Titlis Cliff Walk” [https://www.titlis.ch/en/activities/titlis-cliff-walk] – Europe’s highest suspension footbridge, Chairlift “Ice Flyer” [https://www.titlis.ch/en/activities/ice-flyer] – slides over impressive, up to 10 metres (33 feet) deep crevasses, Titlis Rotair – the world’s first aerial cableway revolving 360° around its own axis, Trübsee snow park, rowing boats on the Trübsee lake, scooters from Gerschnialp, four-lakes hike to Engstlenalp and Melchsee Frutt, the Jochpass Trail is a flow trail suitable for beginners and experienced riders
Food and drink: Restaurants and snack options at all levels (location Stand closed in summer), several restaurants at the summit
Special comments: Direct gondola Engelberg–Trübsee–Stand (without changing)
Tickets: Discounted mountain ascent with Swiss Travel Pass/GA travelcard. Buy your tickets on arrival at the station oronline [https://www.titlis.ch/en]

data.name: Activities in Sattel-Hochstuckli
data.abstract: The family mountain with revolving gondola lift, "Stuckli-Run" summer toboggan run, tubing run, Skywalk pedestrian suspension bridge, bouncy castle and scooter trekking are the highlights here.
data.description:
On the ride to Mostelberg, the colorful 8-seater gondola turns twice on its own axis. Children like to stay at the mountain station, as Rondo's children's world offers almost everything a child's heart desires with its toboggan run, tubing run and numerous bouncy castles and trampolines.

The "Skywalk" foot suspension bridge is 374 m long and one of the longest pedestrian suspension bridges in Europe, crossing the Lauitobel at a height of 58 m. If you don't want to experience the bridge a second time on the way back, take a hike in the direction of Herrenboden, Hochstuckli or Rothenthurm.

Views: From Mostelberg: to the Rigi mountain range, Wildspitz, Lake Aegeri with Morgarten, the Rotenthurm area; from Hochstuckli also the Mythen, the Schwyz basin with Lakes Lauerz and Lucerne, Central Switzerland and the Bernese Alps.
Attractions: Revolving gondola, pedestrian suspension bridge, Rondo's children's world, Geissä Wäg theme and adventure trail, Mythen round trip and panoramic circular hiking trails, high-altitude hike to Haggenegg

data.name: Foxtrail – Puzzle fun in and around Lucerne
data.abstract: In the Lucerne region, the scavenger hunt is available in and around the city of Lucerne, in Weggis-Vitznau, on the Klewenalp, and between Sarnen and Stansstad. The city of light and its surroundings attract not only tourists, but foxes too. Crack codes in the old town, solve puzzles in the surrounding area or decipher clues while surrounded by beautiful panoramic mountain views – there’s no chance of boredom here.
data.description: The fox has laid its trails. Secret messages, hidden clues and many tricky and perplexing challenges show you the way from one stop to the next. You are out on the trail by yourself and never know what’s waiting in store for you – even people familiar with the region are bound to discover new things. The Foxtrail takes you through towns and countryside on foot and using various means of transport. The trails last between 1.5 and 4.5 hours. All you’ll need is good shoes and a mobile phone per group in case you need to call the hotline. Pricing depends on your age and the length of the trail. Simply book online through the website, print the starting instructions and enjoy solving the puzzles!

data.name: Marzilibahn funicular
data.abstract: Since 1885, this funicular has been the fastest route from Bern railway station to the Aare and the Marzili-Bad lido. It now carries a million passengers per year, departing every few minutes on its one-minute journey.
data.description:
The shortest public funicular in Europe. Until 1974 the Marzilibahn was a water ballast funicular. At the top, a tank under the passenger cabin was filled with 3,500 litres of water drawn from the Stadtbach – the excess weight of the car then pulled the other car upwards. You can see one of the historic wooden water ballast wagons not far from the bottom station – another is on display in the Swiss Museum of Transport in Lucerne. 

Today, the fire engine red train that connects Bern’s city centre (300 metres from Bahnhofplatz) to the residential districts on the Aare is powered by electricity. 

Altitude: 539 metres 
How to get there: 
300-metre walk from Bern railway station to Kleine Schanze next to Parliament House, funicular down to the Marzili district 
Views: From the Parliament House terrace down to the Aare and the Schwellenmätteli and Marzili districts, on a clear day as far as the Bernese Alps with the Jungfrau 
Attractions: (accessible by Marzilibahn funicular) Marzili lido, swimming in the River Aare with views of Parliament House 
Food and drink: Restaurant Marzer near the Marzilibahn, Restaurant Marzilibrücke, restaurants in Schwellenmätteli 
Accommodation: City of Bern 
Groups: The youth hostel (double and multi-bed rooms) near the bottom station of the Marzilibahn has a large hall with a stage 
Special comments: You can see one of the historic wooden water ballast wagons not far from the bottom station – another is on display in the Swiss Museum of Transport in Lucerne.

data.name: Lake Lugano Cruises
data.abstract: At Lake Lugano, it is wonderfully easy to escape one’s daily routine: by enjoying a sunbath below palm trees, cruises on the lake or hiking tours through magnificent landscapes.
data.description:
Whether culture, nature or excursions into vibrating nightlife, the lake region offers all of it and then some.

A boat cruise is the perfect way to explore the diversity of the region: Morcote with its stately patrician houses and the Santa Maria del Sasso Church, an important renaissance building at a unique panoramic location with a clock tower dating from the late romantic era; or Gandria, the epitome of a quaint little fishing village at the shores of Lake Lugano.FACTS
Route: Lugano – Gandria – Lugano
Duration: app. 2 to 4 h
EXCURSION TIPS
 * Gandria and surrounding area
 * Monte San Salvatore
 * Swiss Customs Museum
 * Swissminiatur – a miniature Switzerland
 * Monte Generoso

FOOD & BEVERAGES
Coffee, tea, pastries, an innovative kitchen and delicious meals with appealing on-board service.TIMETABLE
All connections here [https://www.lakelugano.ch/en]TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]
RESERVATIONS
No seat reservation required – free seating.

data.name: Foxtrail – Puzzle fun in the Bernese Oberland
data.abstract: In the Bernese Oberland, the scavenger hunt is available in Thun, on the Ballenberg and in Emmental. In these uniquely beautiful surroundings, the fox ensures that chasers are never bored. Whether in the midst of ancient buildings at the Swiss Open-Air Museum, with a spectacular view of the castle in Thun, or looking for the locomotive Emma – there’s something for everyone on these Foxtrails.
data.description: The fox has laid its trails. Secret messages, hidden clues and many tricky and perplexing challenges show you the way from one stop to the next. You are out on the trail by yourself and never know what’s waiting in store for you – even people familiar with the region are bound to discover new things. The Foxtrail takes you through towns and countryside on foot and using various means of transport. The trails last between 1.5 and 4.5 hours. All you’ll need is good shoes and a mobile phone per group in case you need to call the hotline. Pricing depends on your age and the length of the trail. Simply book online through the website, print the starting instructions and enjoy solving the puzzles!

data.name: Brambrüesch – Chur’s local mountain
data.abstract: From a stroll around the old town to the hiking trail, the city of Chur, with its local mountain Brambrüesch, has nature right on its doorstep. Hiking trails, meadows filled with flowers and cycling routes can all be reached in no time at all via cable car.
data.description:
There is hardly any other city in Switzerland where the city and nature can be found as close to one another as they are in Chur. A stroll through the pretty old town [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/old-town-chur/]before or after an adventure in the midst of nature is easy and an obvious choice to make, since it’s so close by.

The view is full of variety – first drawing your eye across the city of Chur [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/chur/]into the Chur Rhine Valley and to the Calanda, then from Piz Beverin to the Heinzenberg, the Safierberge mountains to the Vorab, the Lenzerheide region and into the Schanfigg valley. The boundary stone at the summit that marks the shared border point of the three former Rhaetian confederations is less than a two-hour hike away. The trail continues past this point, often along scenic ridges that lead towards Feldis or Churwalden/Lenzerheide.

There are also shorter hikes [https://www.chur.graubuenden.ch/de/aktivitaeten/sommer/chur-bergbahnen/wanderungen-brambrueesch] to enjoy, however – leading to the “Spundisköpf” viewpoint, for example. The “Bergbaiz [https://www.chur.graubuenden.ch/de/uebersicht-ausflugsziele/bergbaiz]” restaurant, with its spacious sun terrace and playground, invites you to linger a while either before or after your exertions.

Alternatively, if you prefer to grill your own sausages, you’ll find a well-equipped barbecue area [https://www.chur.graubuenden.ch/de/uebersicht-ausflugsziele/feuerstelle-brambrueesch] here, along with a drinking fountain offering fresh drinking water. The “Moorparcours Riedboden [https://www.chur.graubuenden.ch/de/uebersicht-ausflugsziele/moorparcours-riedbodenbrambrueesch]” moorland trail is located right beside the restaurant, offering visitors of all ages the chance to learn about this special biotope.

The two cable cars [https://chur.graubuenden.ch/de/bergbahnen-chur-brambrueesch-winter] have been offering access to this recreation area since 1957/58, the upper section initially being fitted with the elegant two-man gondolas (bubbles), and in the summer, open two-man cabins too. In the winter, ski lifts take skiers all the way up to the Dreibündenstein.

TIP: DISCOUNTS WITH THE GUEST CARD
Even if they are only staying for one night, visitors to Chur can enjoy numerous benefits thanks to theGuest Card [https://www.chur.graubuenden.ch/de/angebot/gaestekarte-chur]: half-price tickets for the mountain railway to Brambrüesch, free use of public transport, free entry to the museum, and many other discounts besides.

ADVENTURE HIGHLIGHT
There’s a whole lot to experience on Chur’s local mountain, the Brambrüesch, such as bike boarding, mountain boarding and dirt surfing – not to mention extended mountain bike tours (on SwitzerlandMobility). Special highlights include the freeride trails in Alpenbikepark Chur, the venue for the 2009 Swiss Mountain Bike and Downhill Championships.

BIKE KINGDOM
With its Alpenbikepark, the “2 RIDE Touren” bike ticket and the many other opportunities for bike tours, Chur’s local mountain is an official part of the BIKE KINGDOM [https://www.bikekingdom.ch/de] of Switzerland. Chur has partnered with Lenzerheide and Arosa as part of this initiative.

MORE INFORMATION
Height of upper station: 1,591m

Height of summit: 2,174m 

Getting there: Train to Chur, bus no. 1 in the direction of Domat/Ems as far as the Brambrüeschbahn valley station, cable car and gondola lift via Känzeli to Brambrüesch. Alternatively: walk from Chur train station through the old town, via Obere Gasse and Obertor to the cable car station.

Views: Across the city of Chur and into the Chur Rhine Valley and to the Calanda, from Piz Beverin to the Heinzenberg, the Safierberge mountains to the Vorab and the Sardona mountain chain, to the Lenzerheide region and into the Schanfigg valley


Attractions: Dreibündenstein circular hikes, the Alpenbikepark with five downhill/freeride trails, Biketicket 2 RIDE enduro tours, bike boarding / scooter downhill trails leading to the Känzeli middle station, Moorparcours Riedboden moorland trail 


Culinary offerings: Various restaurants near the upper station and in the surrounding area 


Overnight stays: Panoramahotel Malixerhof and other (group) accommodation available 


Groups: Group bookings available at the hotels and restaurants on request 


Winter: 20km of natural snow slopes, 5km tobogganing run, winter hiking trails. Brambrüesch is the ideal starting point for the marked snowshoe trails in the Dreibündenstein Snowshoe Arena, which connects Chur’s local mountain with the winter sports regions of Feldis and Pradaschier. 


Special comments: The valley station in the centre of the capital of Graubünden makes Chur a real alpine city.

data.name: Living museum in Tegia Rasuz
data.description: Displaying remarkable attention to detail, Julian and Maurus Cathomas have transported a dilapidated mountain cabin to the village and rebuilt it there: Tegia Rasuz is a living museum. Host Julian Cathomas takes his guests on a journey through time. He cooks traditional country dishes on the fire and regales guests with stories about the life and traditions of his ancestors. This is the place to experience real Graubünden culture.

data.name: Central Alps Passes PostBus Route
data.abstract: Tackling four of the most impressive Swiss Alpine passes by PostBus in one single day, thereby negotiating a total of 10,366 metres altitude: This panorama tour represents the ultimate experience for Alpine enthusiasts!
data.description:
On Grimsel, passengers trundle past glittering reservoir lakes and enjoy many arresting views. Pass Nufenen, Switzerland’s highest Alpine transition negotiable by vehicle, truly gets pulses racing. 

The Gotthard, nicknamed “King of Mountain Passes”, has been an important north-south trans-Alpine connection since the days of the Roman Empire. En route to the Susten Pass, the PostBus crosses no fewer than 25 bridges – and passes through just as many tunnels.FACTS
Route: Meiringen – (Grimsel) – (Nufenen) – (Gotthard) – (Susten) – Meiringen
Distance: 208 km
Duration: 8 h 45 min
EXCURSION TIPS
 * Brienzer Rothorn – steam railway experience reminiscent of times gone by. The mountain route has never been electrified
 * Open air museum Ballenberg – original buildings, local livestock breeds and ancient craftsmanship
 * Reichenbach falls – eye to eye with the creek and the mighty 120 m high Reichenbach waterfall
 * Aare ravine – during ten thousands of years, the Aare has dug a 200-m ravine into the earth on a 1.4 km stretch thus creating a home for itself
 * Grimsel world – a world of hydropower, of mountain and reservoir lakes and of mountain railways, suspension bridges and power plants

FOOD & BEVERAGES
No catering services on the PostBus.TIMETABLE
The Central Alps Passes Route is served by PostBus from June to October.
All connections here [https://www.postauto.ch/en/leisure-offers/excursion-tips/2023/mountain-pass-routes-in-the-central-alps]TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

RESERVATIONS
No seat reservation possible – free seating. Seat reservation required for groups of 10 and more persons. No surcharge applies.

data.name: Lake Geneva Cruises
data.abstract: Boat cruising on Central Europe’s largest inland lake every which way. Passengers can embark and disembark on the Swiss as well as the French side of the lake.
data.description:
The Belle Époque boats have been navigating Central Europe’s largest inland lake for 140 years and offer fantastic cruises between France and Switzerland.

The views from the boat extend from harbours and castles (Chillon, Morges, Rolle, Yvoire among others) over vineyards (Lavaux UNESCO and La Côte) to the snow-covered summits of the Swiss and Savoyan Alps. The boat landings are starting points for many exploration activities like city tours (Geneva, Lausanne, Montreux, Vevey).FACTS

Route: e.g. Geneva – Nyon – Lausanne
Distance: Length of the lake 72 km
Duration: 3 h 45 min

EXCURSION TIPS
 * The Olympic Museum [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/experiences/the-olympic-museum/] in Lausanne
 * The Notre-Dame Cathedral [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/experiences/notre-dame-cathedral/] of Lausanne
 * Chaplin's World [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/experiences/chaplins-world/] in Corsier-sur-Vevey
 * The Cheese Train [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/experiences/cheese-train/] starting in Montreux

FOOD & BEVERAGES

Catering services available in the boat restaurants.TIMETABLE
All connections here [https://www.cgn.ch/en/]TICKET

Ticket
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en-ch/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]


Reservations
No seat reservation required – free seating.

data.name: Jura Round Trip
data.abstract: The watchmaker tour: Swiss world-renowned timepieces represent core values the country stands for – but where are they produced? Not in the country’s big cities, but in the midst of the gently rolling hills of Jura.
data.description:
The journey leads from Neuchâtel and La Chaux-de-Fonds to Saignelégier, Biel and finally Delémont, the canton’s capital with its lovely, carefully restored old town. En route, passengers enjoy the scenic “Three Lakes Region” around Lakes Biel, Murten and Neuchâtel. At the southern tip of Lake Biel lies St. Peter’s Island, the simple beauty of which once inspired Jean-Jacques Rousseau.
FACTS
Route: Neuchâtel – La Chaux-de-Fonds – Glovelier – Delémont – Neuchâtel
Distance: 143 km
Duration: 3 h
EXCURSION TIPS
 * Laténium – a journey through space and time to the origins of mankind in the archaeological museum
 * Areuse ravine – wildly romantic Jura trench with deep insights
 * Creux du Van – a round tour to the impressive rock cirque of Val de Travers
 * La Chaux-de-Fonds Clock museum – the world’s largest museum focusing on clocks, watches and watchmaking
 * Three Lakes Tour – a boat tour on Lakes Biel, Neuchâtel and Murten

FOOD & BEVERAGES
No catering services on the train.TIMETABLE
All connections here [http://www.sbb.ch/en/home.html]TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]
RESERVATIONS
No seat reservation possible – free seating.

data.name: Bernina Express
data.abstract: This panoramic train connects the north of Europe to its south – right through the UNESCO World Heritage site of Rhaetian Railway, passing by glaciers on its way down to palm trees.
data.description:
Crossing the Alps in the Bernina Express certainly is one of the most spectacular ways to do it. Along the way, the Bernina Express rolls over the 65-metre-high Landwasser Viaduct, the signature structure of the Rhaetian Railway and the UNESCO World Heritage site. Altogether the train passes through 55 tunnels and over 196 bridges on its way from Chur to Tirano. Travellers are treated to marvellous sights during their journey, like the Montebello curve with a view of the Bernina massif, the Morteratsch glacier, the three lakes Lej Pitschen, Lej Nair and Lago Bianco, the Alp Grüm and the Brusio Circular Viaduct. The journey can be extended aboard the Bernina Express Bus from Tirano to Lugano from February to November (daily in summer).

FACTS BERNINA EXPRESS (TRAIN)
Route: Chur/St. Moritz – Tirano (Italy) or vice versa Distance: 144 km Duration: 4 h - 4 h 30 min FACTS BERNINA EXPRESS BUS
Route: Tirano (Italy) – Lugano or vice versa Distance: 90 km Duration: 3 h EXCURSION TIPS
 * Arosa Railway – from Chur to Arosa within one hour. On just 26 km, the train negotiates an amazing 1000 m in altitude
 * Railway Museum Albula – over 600 exhibits from more than 100 years of railway history, e.g. one of the last «Crocodile»-Locomotives
 * Gandria – a picturesque little town at the foot of Monte Bré
 * Monte San Salvatore – one of the most beautiful scenic outposts along Lake Lugano
 * Palm Express – rich-in-contrast, roughly four-hour postbus drive from Lugano to St. Moritz
 * Mountain excursion Diavolezza [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/diavolezza-1/]

FOOD & BEVERAGES
 * The Bernina Express minibar offers delicious snacks and refreshing beverages
 * The train does not feature a dining car. The guests spend their lunchtime in the Italian town of Tirano

TIMETABLE
 * Summer and winter timetable panoramic trains [https://tickets.rhb.ch/en/pages/bernina-express]

data.name: Thurbo Seelinie (lake line)
data.abstract: The railway line between St. Gallen, Stein am Rhein and Schaffhausen runs along a unique lake and river landscape. Hop off and on wherever you like – “Thurbo” trains operate at half-hour intervals.
data.description:
The voyage on the “Thurbo” along Lake Constance and the Rhine leads you through the Cantons of St. Gallen, Thurgau and Schaffhausen. The many villages with picturesque historic old towns along the route invite visitors to exploration tours. Are you interested in culture? Visit one of the many museums along the “lake line”. Those who appreciate the good things in life take a seat in a cosy restaurant and savour the local specialities. 

Peace, quiet and leisureliness are quite important during this travel experience. Guests are in no hurry: having got off the train, the next one is never more than 30 minutes away. The lake line is a railway and nature treat for everyone. Insider tip: For the best view of the scenery from the train seat, choose the side of the train where the windows face the lake and river!

FACTS
Route: St. Gallen – Stein am Rhein – Schaffhausen and vice-versa Distance: 86 km Duration: 1 h 52 min EXCURSION TIPS
 * Historic old towns ofSchaffhausen [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/schaffhausen/], Diessenhofen [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/diessenhofen/], Stein am Rhein [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/stein-am-rhein/], Steckborn [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/steckborn/], Berlingen, Ermatingen [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/ermatingen/], Gottlieben, Arbon [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/arbon/]and Rorschach [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/rorschach/].
 * Diverse offer of museums, e.g. Museum zu Allerheiligen [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/museum-zur-allerheiligen/]in Schaffhausen, Napoleon Museum [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/arenenberg-castle-and-the-napoleonic-museum/]in Salenstein, Museum of History and Oldtimer Museum in Arbon.
 * Historic town ofSt. Gallen [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/destinations/st-gallen/]with theAbbey Library [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/st-gallen-abbey-district/](part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site) with more than 170,000 books and scripts.
 * Part of the lake line can be travelled on a lake boat [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/experiences/swiss-navigation-company-untersee-am-rhein/]in both directions – e.g. between Stein am Rhein and Schaffhausen.

FOOD & BEVERAGES
There is no catering on the train.

TIMETABLE
Trains depart between 5am and 11pm at 30-minute intervals in both directions
To the timetable [https://www.sbb.ch/de]

TICKET
This route is fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard.
Book Swiss Travel System tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

RESERVATION
It is not possible to make a reservation on this line.

data.name: Rhine Cruises Basel
data.abstract: There is always something to experience aboard the flotilla of the Basle passenger cruise company: lock passages between Basle and Rheinfelden, city and harbour tours, rich brunch offer and much more.
data.description:
The city and harbour tours take roughly one hour. They take visitors past the charming facades of the Basle old town, Basle cathedral and the ancient city walls near the St. Alban valley, further along the Kleinbasle Rhine shores up to the border triangle and the Basle Rhine harbour, which is the loading and unloading station of countless goods.

The two-and-a-half hour Rhine lock journey takes passengers along the Rhine shores from Basle to Rheinfelden. Two locks at Augst and Birsfelden have to be negotiated on the Swiss as well as the German side. Also, the vessel docks at several boat landings: at Kaiseraugst and at the former Roman city Augusta Raurica among others.FACTS
Route: Basel – Rheinfelden – Basel

EXCURSION TIPS
 * Beyeler Foundation – the museum with some of the most famous masterpieces of classical modernism 
 * Brewery Feldschlösschen – exploring one of the most beautiful beer breweries in the world 
 * Basle Zoo – the world of animals in a fascinating park landscape 
 * Tinguely Museum 
 * Aqua Basilea – the bath offering a mixture of action and relaxation 

FOOD & BEVERAGES
Diverse meals, local offers, surprising aperitif snacks and an extensive selection of beverages available in the boat restaurants.TIMETABLE
Basle passenger cruise services operates all year round.
All connections here [https://www.basel.com/en/activities-excursions/boat-trips]RESERVATIONS
A table reservation in advance is recommended.

data.name: Lake Constance Cruises
data.abstract: The High Rhine between Schaffhausen and Stein am Rhein offer one of the most delightful river cruises while the lower lake is rightly considered the jewel of Lake Constance.
data.description:
Lake Constance is Europe’s third largest inland lake. The “white flotilla” links all the villages and sights on the shores of the lake. 

On the Swiss side of Lake Constance on its southwestern shores, the quaint towns of Romanshorn, Arbon and Rorschach with their tranquil old towns are well worth a visit. The same is true for picturesque places like Gottlieben, Ermatingen and Stein am Rhein on the shores of the lower lake. At the other end of the lake, boats cruise from Rorschach to Rheineck along the romantic Old Rhine river route.FACTS
Route: e.g. Rorschach – Lindau – Rorschach
Distance: Length of the lake 62 km
Duration: app. 2 h

EXCURSION TIPS
 * Mainau Island – enjoying the blaze of colours and wonderful fragrances of the flower island 
 * Lake dwelling museum Unteruhldingen
 * Säntispark – Adventure bath with large wellness facilities and adventure waterpark 

FOOD & BEVERAGES

Breakfast, fresh meals and an extensive selection of beverages available in the boat restaurants.TIMETABLE
All connections here [http://www.sbsag.ch/fahrplan-preise/kursschifffahrt.html]TICKET
Most routes are fully covered by the Swiss Travel Pass (Flex) and GA travelcard. On all other routes, there is a discount.
Book tickets [https://www.myswitzerland.com/en/planning/transport-accommodation/tickets-public-transport/]

RESERVATIONS
 No seat reservation required – free seating.

data.name: Grimsel Pass
data.abstract: The Grimsel Pass links the Hasli Valley in the Bernese Oberland with Goms in Valais. The pass road runs through a wild, sparsely grown mountainous region marked by granite rocks, reservoir lakes, and power plants.
data.description:
Innertkirchen near the holiday resort of Meiringen is the starting point of two impressive pass roads. The Susten Pass leads eastward to Central Switzerland. Southward, a splendidly constructed road climbs in large bends in the direction of the Grimsel Pass. In the Guttannen, the “Crystal Village”, one can admire crystals of all sizes in the Prospector’s Museum. The road ascends through canyons of wild beauty that get narrower and narrower. Hydroelectric power plants, high voltage power lines and high reservoir lake walls dominate the landscape on the northern side of the Grimsel Pass. 

With a gradient of 106%, the Gelmerbahn, the world’s steepest funicular, ascends from Handeck to the picturesque Gelmer Lake, the starting point of a hiking loop around the reservoir lake (approx. 2-hour hike). A second train, the aerial cable car from Handeck to Gerstenegg, is partially operational for skiers during the winter months, when the Grimsel Pass Road is closed. narrower and narrower. Hydroelectric power plants, high voltage power lines and high reservoir lake walls dominate the landscape on the northern side of the Grimsel Pass. 

You travel past steep rocks and through tunnels to the dam of the Räterichbodensee (a reservoir lake), and a little later to the dam of the Grimsel Lake. Near the Grimsel Lake’s dam, you will find the Grimsel Hospiz atop a rock, the Nollen (1980m). Today it is a cozy hotel with a wonderful view of the Lauteraarhorn and the lake. An Adventure Trail leads from the Grimsel Hospiz back to Handeck through an area with one of the richest mineral deposits in the Alps. 

In the past, mule traders transported Swiss cheese on dizzying paths to Piedmont. The Piedmont traders brought wine, rice, corn and leather in exchange. The exchange trade often took place in the old Hospiz, which is today flooded by the reservoir lake. An exhibition at Grimsel Hospiz informs visitors about the use of hydropower for generating electricity. The Power Plant management offers a guided tour of the facilities that starts in Innertkirchen and takes several hours.

On the ridge of the pass (at 2165 meters) is the Totensee, or Lake of the Dead, which got its name during the Napoleonic wars. On the Valaisian side one travels on a well-constructed road with many long bends down to Gletsch in Obergoms (1759m). Here one has a fine panoramic view of the Rhone Glacier and the Furka Pass road. In the huge Grand Hotel Glacier du Rhône in Gletsch one can still enjoy the early 19th century atmosphere of the Alpine Passes’ heyday. Gletsch is also the starting point of the Furka Steam Railway.
